A survival game in an uninhabited island based on an online game, now where have I heard of something similar to this?
Story: 8/10
The story was nicely done, even though it's a bit unoriginal. Though, Btooom! put its own twist in it by using rules from an online game called Btooom! (not a real game if you didn't know). The story had rape in it, and that's one thing I didn't like about the anime. If you're going to include rape in a survival game story, then you might as well make this whole series a hentai. Yes, I know it sounds realistic, but at leastactually keep it within the uninhabited island, and not in someone's high-school life. One more thing is that the rape was also just a bit overdone, because at the start, there was rape and maybe 4 minutes later, it shows a guy trying to 'punish' a girl. Though that probably adds some effect to the psychological side. There wasn't much sci-fi, other than the ability to find players that are close to you with a 'sonar ping' and BIMs that have unique abilities, such as timer bombs, cracker bombs or even implosions. It's very violent, but hey it's a survival game-type anime, you'd probably expect something like that. If you are the type who likes a slice-of-life, comedy-type anime, then you probably should stop reading this review.


Art: 7/10


I've heard a lot of things on how the character designs were from Death Note (I've actually never watched Death Note) and yes Light Yagami and Sakamoto Ryouta look similar. The animation and the art are actually quite nice, even though the character designs do look a bit 'old'. The colors can catch your eye easily.


Sound: 8/10


The OST isn't too loud but sometimes can be used unnecessarily, because there was this one scene where it was serious, but a 'sports-event' soundtrack was playing. Didn't bother me that much, as the OST didn't stand out that much, though it did make some scenes blood-rushing. The 1st OP is probably one of my favorite OPs, because it somehow motivated me. The line "the game has only just begun" gave me goosebumps and it got stuck in my head. The OP feels like it was made just for the OP for Btooom!. The 2nd OP didn't give me the same feeling the 1st one did, but it was alright. The ED was more for an old romance anime, but it sounded relaxing.


Character: 8/10


Sakamoto Ryouta, a full-time NEET (Not in Education, Employment, or Training) and is the top Japanese player and is one of the best in the world. Sometimes, he can be stupid and act like a child, but other times, he's epic and smart. He is a kind person who thinks of others sometimes, but also has dirty intentions such as almost raping Himiko, but fortunately stopped himself before it escalated.


Himiko, a highschool girl who had a normal life until one day, where it all got twisted. She is shunned by her fellow classmates, even her best-friend, who now hates her. She hates all men except Ryouta because she is married to him virtually, but not knowing until later on. She's a fragile woman and sometimes can be weak. She almost gets raped quite a bit in the anime. Though apparently more rape = more love for Ryouta. Anime logic.


Enjoyment: 9/10


Survival game-type anime always work out nicely most of the time and I can't see why people are giving this low reviews. I really enjoyed this anime, even though I would be skipping out some boring parts.


Overall: 8/10


There are a lot of survival game-type anime. If you liked Btooom, then I suggest you check out Mirai Nikki. Would I re-watch this anime? Maybe, because it needs A SECOND SEASON.

This show is like if they tried to put Yagami Light into Sword Art Online but with the WRONG personality.
6/10
Can't speak for the manga but the anime is pretty mediocre.
It has a READ THE MANGA-ending, and gosh do I hate those. The characters seem intresting enough, but I never really bonded with anyone exept the MC and his gril. They gave characters they wanted us to feel sorry for way to little screen-time, which is understandable considering the shows lenght, but it's also legitimate critique.
It's nice for a 12-episoder, and if you like kind MCs then you might enjoy it alot.
But in this type ofsetting I want a character willing to kill the fucking brat. Someone with a darker tone, less naive and willing to utilise their knowledge from the get go.\n
Not some kid with half his brain from Yagami and the other half from Tinky Winky the telletubby.\n\n
The story had just as much potential as SAO and all other game-turns-real-stories have. Which is alot, also unfortunately wasted in most cases.\n\n
Later Edit: Now I read it so now I CAN speak for the manga!\n\n
Don't read it. (jk it's alright, nothing special, MC still turns from zero to hero in half a page with no explanation as of how)

Btooom! is a pretty solid series. It's short with only 12 episodes and it does leave a gaping hole at the end due to the manga still being ongoing. Despite the gaping hole of an ending, it does a really great job on delivery. It's filled with great characters, and it's not the action series that it sounds to be from the synopsis. 
As the synopsis says, it does pretty much go from him playing the online version to waking up in a jungle forced to play the real life version. It's not a weird "snap your fingers and he's there" transition like I wasafraid it would be. There is a mild setup and then we get the background story of who, what, when, where, why and how through flashbacks as the story progresses. 


The supporting cast is dealt with much the same, meaning we get introduced to them and then see their lives and how they got there through flashbacks as well. It deals a little with the psychology of the experience, but a lot of the depth comes from why there are all there. It's a bit twisted at times both in the flashbacks and on the island (of course). All of this is complimented with some pretty well done voice acting that drives the emotional attachment developed to each of the characters in the story.


I really felt the animation and artwork was done pretty well, and the music was integrated nicely into the flow of the series. It's nice that they didn't mess this up in post production. You can have all of cards lined up and then the guys behind the scenes can easily ruin it. Btooom has some decent production value.


Don't let all of this praise fool you. It does have that gaping hole at the end, and it does slow down quite a bit towards the end. As I mentioned, this isn't much of an "action" anime series. The main character should be able to easily kill everyone on the island, but he's attempting to play a survival game without turning into a murderer. It's almost to a fault at times, especially with the intense beginning that sets you up for an action thriller that never matures.


Thankfully the story works, and I was a little relieved that it was not an action thriller all the way through. I really enjoyed the overall theme and feel of this series. I decided to watch the anime before reading the manga due to the 12 episode length, so I will at least get to enjoy the manga next.


I highly recommend this series, it is a solid 8, but due to it's faults it's easy to see that it could have been better. Definitely a must see in my book.

Btooom! 12 Episodes Long.
"Kill or Be Killed", Or "Lets work together and Survive!"
At first i thought that this anime was going to be a complete joke. Your average "Damsel in Distress", and "Prince Charming". But wow, was i wrong. There is so much Emotion, the plot twists are amazing, The characters are breath taking! This anime has it all, and all of it is in the little 12 episodes! I Literally One-Sat it all, in the past 4 hours i've watched all 12 episodes. I've had no background information about this except for the few reviews that were recommened to me by different anime. Thatis how amazing this anime is.

-

Story: 9/10


Starting off with your MC, you see him waking up in some sort of different "land" than he should be! And from then, you "hear" his reactions, which tell you that "OH This voice acting is just Perfect! I won't get annoyed by their voices..Phew!"

So with that out of the picture, the story follows as one of your regular Survivor Anime's. Kill or be Killed. That's the motto that is flowing through the character's mind. 

Slowly, Ryouta begins his journey and meets new people. However having lost his memories somehow, he recieves help; which is very rare. With the new people he's meeting, he goes on an adventure to try and find a way how to outsmart the game. Leaving behind a ton of plot twists, Empathetic moments, Amazing Fights, And strategic gameplay!

-

Art: 10/10


This art is WAY better than most anime's out there! Every bit of detail everywhere! Where you have your average anime show a character in distress with very little details on their faces/aura, you have Btooom! With AMAZING details EVERYWHERE, Be it wrinkles (in the right places), Gorey Injuries, or even Traumatic Moments in characters Past. They certainly depicted everything with such emotion and thought.

-

Sound: 9/10


I'm usually not a fan of Music, but the music added in for the action scenes/happy scenes/sad scenes certainly took my breath away. You'd think they'd play the same soundtrack throughout each episode? Hah! No way! They've made the music fit Perfectly with the scenes they deserved. Very well done for the music.

-

Character: 10/10


The character development was OUTSTANDING! For just 12 episodes, i thought much less was going to be given to us, But man was i wrong. The development is so well-done. It shows you the characters background, and how it impacts them in the present time. It really made me just want to jump into my screen and hug them! It's so good, like words can NOT even describe it! For example, Kousuke Kira, ( don't worry no spoilers will be shown!) is just one of those characters that deserves the spotlight. Being thrown into a situation, with the disgusting horros of his past. . and then chucked into a new reality, and how the Actor voices him is just the definition of PERFECTION! And this goes for all of the characters! It's just perfect!!

-

Enjoyment: 10/10


Overall, This anime was very realistic. I could take in many situations and put them into my own real life. I Enjoyed every bit of that. When it comes to whether an anime fits your perspectives this anime has it in the Bag! The anime deserves so much more, It's too bad that the general summary of this anime is based off of Games. If it was something like adventure that didn't have to be limited to Gaming rules then maybe it would've got a lot of better reviews. However, do NOT let it hold you against watching this! It's just a short 12 episode Anime, which deserves to be watched by everyone! Atleast the first 4 episodes, that's just a small hour-ish. Give it a chance if you're not fond of gaming anime's, because i for sure am NOT a fan of gaming anime's, but this was an exception.

-

Overall: 9/10


Overall, this anime is a masterpiece. However it did not recieve a 10 from me, only because of it's ending. Like most Masterpiece anime's, they start off with a bang then fall off towards the end. HOWEVER! This anime's ending isn't like what I usually see. The ending was very trustworthy and I do hope it gets a second season! It deserves so much. The manga is still continueing i think, and the wiki on the characters are still being updated so you will still love your characters even after the anime is finished!


I hope you all will enjoy this anime. Even if gaming Anime's aren't your thing, I'm pretty sure this anime will be one that you'll remember.

As I just watched BTOOOM! about 3 years after the initial episode, its premise is actually a common theme of most series. Yes, about a NEET that is somehow trapped in a situation where their life at stake. It's so common that I even need to think twice or thrice to take such a show because there's a common follow-up of the series. It become a comedy that forget how the pinch in their life and in the last episodes, the situation become so dangerous that make the episodes before is a summer breeze. And how about BTOOOM!?
BTOOOM! take a nice approach by using asurvival game as its core, a common thing of how Hollywood action movie/series. But, it didn't forget that it's an anime by using a game and NEET theme. It's quite a good start. As the story goes, BTOOOM! take us to know how the game works, how the mechanism itself, and how the rule-I think it's important to do this as a survival theme because we can't just let a guy die without a reason, right? Too bad, there are several detail that's somehow is quite bothering. One of them is how the 2 years-NEET protagonist is somehow can do all the run and action with a good stamina. Though, I was indifferent about it after several episodes. As the ending come, I think once again that this show is really using Hollywood recipe of action movie. Win against an enemy, got a friend, a betrayal, then closed by a kiss scene with the heroine. And I think they brought it well.


I love how the character design made without using a moe-style too much. And that design is quite good to take this series seriously as survival theme. Though, there are several gap between design of a character to another. Next, I like their action scene even after they didn't use CG to do the bomb explosion. I actually expect some CG on the explosion, but a hand-drawn couldn't be said as a bad artwork. As a whole, the artwork is good.


The sound work isn't really notable. I feel the explosion of every bomb is same regardless of the power. The BGM is not that bad, but it's isn't good either to feel a thrilling from the tense situation.


The character is quite bad for me. How the character interact, their questionable development, even how a weird conclusion of a certain episode is still bothering me. Despite that, the development of the protagonist is good. Though at first it's questionable how he's a jerk, but I love how he has his own ideal to do a thing, how he realize how jerk he is and know the reason of it, it's good to see how his development in later episode is. 


Overall, it's a good series. It's a good watch to see how a jerk become a hero and how the action scene goes with explosion despite a bad work on it. I would like to recommend this series to everyone who love an action with a good development on protagonist.


Thanks for reading my review!

“Why is it always the game ones?” -Me
Survival is the number one thing everything living is wired to do. We’re driven to stay alive in any way possible, and so is everything else we live with here on planet Earth. That’s why we do things, sometimes horrible, unthinkable things, in the spur of the moment when our life is in danger. 
There really is a lot of death game anime that use this unwritten rule on a psychological basis, and my god is it rare to find a good one. Unfortunately, Btooom!, is not one of those hidden gems, and I’m here to explain why.
---PLOT---
Btooom!’sstory lays itself out with a death game set on a deserted island that’s based off an in-universe console game of the same name. The characters are given bombs (called BIMs) that each have a different attribute, and imbedded in their left hands are chips that can track other players. The point of the game? Kill as many players as possible and collect up to eight of those chips so you can escape the island. Why?


Well… It’s alluded to, but the circumstances surrounding why is just BARELY grazed over because of Btooom’s! improper ending.


When the anime begins though, it actually starts out with some promise. There was good emotional depth, (at the time) and there’s a clear connection to the obsession of hiding in your room all day, playing video games (or doing anything) excessively, and how the real life equivalent would be… psychologically difficult. Plus, with the “last one standing” plot; we get a demonstration of people reverting back to survival-mode, trying to get off the island and back to reality. For what its worth, all the players in the game have defining backstories that involve sexual assault, murder, and domestic abuse.


But this is where it quickly falls apart, because it tries SO HARD to be “gritty,” and for lack of a better adjective, “edgy.” These backstories are obviously there to gather audience sympathy, and explain the mental conditions of all the people playing, which would be a great dynamic if they weren’t portrayed as shallowly and one dimensional as they are. It’s direct in that we basically know that, “they were abused/assaulted etc, and that’s why they’re so messed up.” But the backstory alone doesn’t do enough to convince the audience that the psychological problems they have are realistic, because everyone acts flatly, creating a domino effect of predictability with no plausibility in sight. They stumble into trouble in a manner that’s almost as if they want to get killed, prompting the question, “Wow, are you really that stupid?” (They run directly into the path of incoming BIM’s without any forethought) and they only ever act one way; kill or be killed. There’s no dimension here, its like they’re all machines.


As far as the tactical aspects that come with a video game inspired death match goes, each character gets a different type of BIM, (one is a mine, another explodes upon impact, that sort of thing) and this would actually work if they knew how to aim when they’re throwing the damn thing. Even if it explodes, the main characters are able to avoid its immediate radius anyway by jumping or dodging, crafting more than enough noticeable conveniences along the line of the story. The strategy is completely reliant on convenient circumstance, and to further screw up the narrative by tampering with the pacing, the story likes to flip flop between a completely useless subplot that takes place between the two main characters in the actual game of Btooom!, that can only be there to force them into being love interests. It doesn’t flesh them out to any degree because they’re interaction is limited to being only a short conversation at wedding and a party, so their “chemistry” doesn’t even exist.


And even at the end of it all, there’s no solid explanation to the purpose of the death game, but this is a very common problem in anime. Either it didn’t acquire the right following for it to continue and still make money off of merchandise, or it caught up to production of the manga. Regardless, it’s a lackluster, unoriginal story that has no more to offer other than uninspired “edginess” and can’t even hold suspense or tension because it’s so predictable. The tactics are nothing but contrived and badly masked plot armor.

---Plot Score: -Terrible- ---




---CHARACTERS---

The main character Ryouta Sakamoto (who looks scarily similar to Light Yagami) is a 22 year old, Btooom! addicted NEET. Due to unknown circumstances, he’s sent off to play the real version of Btooom! that he’d spent so long getting good at.


Like the rest of the anime, he’s shown with promise. He had a trait of being genuinely emotionally affected with how he had to kill others, and it works out really well in the immediate beginning.


But this concept drops directly afterwards and he ends up being both bland and subconsciously indecisive of how he normally acts, without any development or exploration into what makes him tick. We know he became a shut-in because his family had never actually acted loving to him, but that backdrop doesn’t work when he’s constantly unsure about his personality. What I mean by this is that he’s never the same guy, one minute he’s a cunning mastermind at this game, (as he was explained to be one of the top players in real life) and the next he’s an incapable ditz who somehow is able to escape the unrealistically small blast radius of a f****ing hand grenade. We know he’s going to come out unscathed and pwn n00bs because of his brilliant “strategies” that only he can think up, and is somehow thin as a twig and can outrun anyone, despite having spent years in his room all day. 


The secondary main character, Abnormally Large-Breasted Himiko, is not any better. Her backstory involves a plunder of emotional trauma from attempted assault, and later when she’s cast into the game she’s molested, causing a fear and distrust of men. Admittedly, this is an interesting backstory for a character considering the traumatic influence of her past life, but it just feels so utterly misused and as a consequence, forced. She’s regularly taken captive, forcing her into the “damsel in distress” archetype, which wholly mistreats that capable backstory she has as she never ends up developing out of those trust issues, making it nothing but irresponsibly offensive and downright ironic, because the one thing she can actually trust is exactly what she’s afraid of.


To add insult to injury, her backdrop is even further insulted because its used as a reason she can smack the protagonist like the baka he is! Because HE’S DEFFINITELY THE PERVERT HERE IF YOU WALK OUT OF A SHOWER DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF HIM. I don’t know why having the two main, opposite gendered characters be love interests is so compulsory, but it has to be done right. And it isn’t done right.


The other characters are completely bland and void of direction, as the only thing they’re defined by is a dark motivation, one, specific trait, (doubt, insanity, etc) and a limited backstory, all of which pertaining to “dis guy is nuts cause he had a messed up life.” They only ever act violent, so it’s never hard to predict what they will do next. 


But there IS a tiny, ray of hope with the character Taira Kiyoshi. Out of all the characters, he’s the most developed and explored, with a backstory that is far less forced and believable than the rest of the cast. He’s a man who is both clearly affected negatively by the life he had outside the game, and sees now that he wants to correct those misgivings and get off the island. Taira is really the only character with an understandable motive.


Unfortunately, none of the other characters… have that. Their lives suck, and there’s nary a time when its totally understandable that they’d just jump right in to kill each other instead of at least trying to band together for survival. 


“But that’s part of the show! We see how desperate and evil they act to get home again!”


This would work if there were a slow decline from sanity to insanity from the cast, but they’re all crooks and killers as soon as they’re dropped in. They just decide to listen to whoever put them there, and kill others without hesitation. While there is a reason they’re all this way, it’s part of the unresolved nature as to why they’re playing the game to begin with. 

---Characters Score: -Poor- ---




---ANIMATION---

I believe in giving credit where credit is due, because this animation is goddamn gorgeous. It should be too; it was done by Madhouse after all.


The style is sharp and smoothly cut, with a lot of the colors being browns, tropical greens and grays due to the amount of foliage. The attention to detail in the backgrounds is amazing, where tree trunks are realistically barked, (with variance in bark size and color) leaves are all individually detailed, (most have visible veins) and the water, especially the ocean, looks like something directly out of a photograph. 


There are some really standout character designs too, especially Abnormally Large Breasted Himiko, who’s skirt pattern is a camouflage print that stays stationary as she moves, a stylistic choice that’s common in American animation. But there are also a few duds in the cast design wise. Ryouta for example, who’s a carbon copy of Light Yagami.


But otherwise, is some really high quality stuff. The explosions are always detailed in the finest of hotter colors, rust appears as if it’s actually there, and the environment around the characters is as convincing as it gets for a two-dimensional animation. (Might I add, reptilian scales look FABULOUS) Even if theres under-whelming action (the characters are literally just throwing bombs at each other) The movement and style looks beautiful anyway.

---Animation Score: -Amazing- ---




---SOUNDTRACK---

The soundtrack is wonderful too. It has a cinematic feeling, an ensemble of both thematic, powerful music that assists the (nonexistent) suspense, and upbeat drum tracks that follow the action. I noticed several piano/violin pieces that belong in an award winning drama, and those were brilliantly put together. 


Anyone who’s heard Nano’s opening themes know they’re done best when played over a panoramic shot of every character standing in the wind like a badass. Her opening, “No pain, No game” is a punk piece that fits wonderfully for the atmosphere of Btooom!


As for the ending, May’n’s “Aozora” is a tranquil, mellow song that works wonderfully as well, paired with the beautiful visuals of the credits. 

--- Soundtrack Score: -Amazing- ---


AFTER REPORT:


PROS:

-	Amazing, beautiful music

-	GORGEOUS animation

-	For what its worth, initially has a lot going for it emotionally

MIXED:

-	Open ending, room for new season and for the story to go up in quality

CONS:

-	Completely forced “edginess” that is terribly misused and offensive

-	100% predictable, as the characters always act a certain way

-	Bullshit “tactics,” that have no convincing basis and are pulled out of the writer’s ass to keep the main characters alive. 

-	The main characters act like they don’t know others are trying to kill them, but almost always end up unscathed anyway

-	Overall bland, undefined cast that doesn’t have any semblance of originality or personality and horribly forced “romance” sub-plot

-	Allusion to what is happening and how, but not why because it never concludes, making the base story horribly unoriginal


OVERALL: -Terrible-

Btooom!, has no polished, complete story in sight. It lacks in nearly every single way, and cannot be enjoyed by anyone who is looking for a deep, complex and original plot that concludes, or well-developed, consistent and explored characters. It would be fine if it were mindless violence but it tries, so… so hard to be deep and realistic. So that entertainment aspect is out the window.


Though I will say this; the story is open enough and has enough potential for it to go in many different directions. If this is indeed a cour one, then I will definitely watch cour two, because as it stands, it has enough to flip itself around.


But for now, it doesn’t have that.


I give Btooom! a pathetic 3/10

NO PAIN, NO GAME. THE CURTAIN RISES OF KILLING WITH A BOMB PLAY.

Enter the world of Btooom! through the eyes of Ryouta, a world-class player of the video game Btooom, a battle arena FPS game where guns are absent and bombs called BIMs are the only weapons available.  Through unfortunate circumstances, he gets kidnapped and ends up on an island with real-life BIMs by his side.  He soon realizes that he is trapped in a real-life game of Btooom! on the island and his only way to leave is to win.
It’s a land of kill or be killed.
It’s pretty clear from the get-go that there’s way more to the forced game of survival than whatmeets the eye.  Btooom!’s pacing is fast enough to maintain constant interest. The show begins as a straight up survival thriller where Ryouta goes through hell’s worth of bombs and violence, desperately applying his skills in the video game as survival and battle tactics so he can live for another day.  Of course, there is an external force working behind the scenes that prevents the outside from interfering with the “game.”  A change in focus from the battle of survival to figuring out the method behind the madness takes place.  The plot’s flow is fairly straightforward, but it overall feels very fluid and not thrown together. Btooom! reveals itself to be not just an anime about throwing bombs to keep living, but a strong presentation of reading between the lines and defeating the system that restricts the freedom of the island’s inhabitants.


Despite the story being told mainly through the eyes of Ryouta, there’s a healthy amount of screen time and development for the supporting cast.  Each character has a respectable personality and some even have compelling pasts that all add up to reveal the big secret behind Btooom! Island.  No one particularly stands out since they’re all unique in their own way, but no one’s left behind either.


The characters’ interactions with each other vary in many different ways.  One would expect that every encounter on the island always leads to explosions and extreme adrenaline levels, but it’s easy to notice that not everyone is dead-set on staining their hands for their own sake.  Not even a Btooom! master like Ryouta can have the same killing intent as he does in the virtual world.  His skills in the game are refined to defend himself and destroy his foes, but he still has a rational sense of reality and wants to find a way to escape the bloodshed that was forced upon everyone on the island.


The art and animation does not try to impress anyone with movie quality animation and pretty colors.   Fancy special effects take a back seat as the art shows its focus on the fact that Btooom! is still set in the real world despite having video game rules set upon it.  The island environment is not portrayed as the dream beach area, but drawn as close to a real island as 2D drawing can make it.  It is a nice touch to see how the island slowly transitions from a peaceful resort to a bloody battleground of explosions as the episodes fly by.


Even though explosions aren’t the most exciting visual effects for anime and Btooom! is all about bombs, the action is kept very real.  There’s nothing top-notch to marvel at here, but the animation delivers and looks very fluid when intensity unfolds.


Openings and ending aren’t all to what defines the sound of an anime, but nano really drives it home with powerful music that pumps the viewers up and portray the image of Btooom! quite accurately.


Outside of that, here’s nothing new about all the other sounds.  Explosions sound like explosions, and there is no reason to be surprised by much of anything in the SFX and voice acting department.  They all get the job done.  The background music is subtle and it’s really most noticeable during action and times of suspense. The mood is well-promoted by the BGM, and combined with nano’s impressive performance, a promising soundtrack can be something to look forward to.


There’s no “boring” part in this anime, especially considering the likable cast of characters, the moderately fast pacing, and the intense moments that lead to engaging bomb fights.  It’s very easy to stay glued to the screen when all these factors are playing.


Overall, not only is Btooom! a true blast to watch, but all the major themes that apply to standard survival anime are shown with a noticeable presence. The themes are not up for self-interpretation.  Btooom! is here to tell a message about being forced out of normal society and balancing personal morals with what is really needed to continue living in whatever conditions that are forced upon the outcasts.


Final ratings:


Storytelling (40%):  8 -> 3.2

Characters (30%):  8 -> 2.4

Visuals (10%):  8 -> .8

Sounds (10%):  8 -> .8

Enjoyment Value (10%):  9 -> .9


3.2 + 2.4 + .8 + .8 + .9 = 8.1


Final Rating: 8.1

So wow I was...hehe..."Blown away" by this show...that pun may need some explanation if you have no idea what this show is about.
There are lots of shows nowadays that follow the style of 'Oh no, we're trapped in our favorite video game. What ever will we do?', examples being obviously Sword Art Online and Log Horizon. Log Horizon fixates more on the RPG aspect and the characters actually enjoy their new setting. SAO on the other hand is more of a WoW-esque game where players literally fight for their lives to escape. Btooom! on the other hand, is the best of both worlds, where playersare familiar with their setting (AKA The game Btooom!), but have a strong urge to survive.


We all have people in our lives that we would like to be rid of and never see again. But how far are you willing to stress that emotion? Btooom! follows the story of Ryouta, the best player of the game 'Btooom!' in Japan, rated number 10 in the world. However, because of this, he is ridiculously anti-social and literally drops out of school to play this game. Now at age 22, that becomes an issue, for he has no job and his nonstop gaming is tearing his family apart essentially. In fact, this leads to the main plot. Recently, letters have been popping up in Japan stating that if you write someone's name, someone you want to disappear, and send that name to an address, you'll get a ton of money and that person will vanish. People think it's just a chain letter gimmick, however, it is quite real. Certain people whose names are written on these letters are taken and dropped on an island in the middle of the Pacific with no way out except for one method: Collect 7 chips. What are chips? They are surgically implanted stones placed on the hands of the contestants and the only way to remove the chip is to have the person die. Obviously, conflict ensues. The catch here is that the conflict on the island follows the game Btooom! where the only weapon one can use are different variations of bombs (see, now that pun makes sense).


I've been talking about the plot for a long time so I suppose I should move on to other aspects. The characters are all great and have very well done attributes and quirks, ranging from murderous 14 year old kid to a lawyer etc. Basically, there are all kinds on this island fighting to survive.


Animation work is really well done, especially where it needs to shine most, that being during scenes of action and explosions. The soundtrack is also, personally, one of the best I've heard recently. It's subtle, but adds a lot to the show.


I could go on for a lot longer saying why I loved this show, but I'll let the positives and negatives handle most of that for me.


Positives:

+The two opening themes, 'No Pain No Game' and 'Exist' are both really good and fit the show perfectly

+Animation and sound is solid, espacially during moments of action

+Characters are diverse and all have their own little quirks or memorable attributes

+The romance in this show is one of the best I've seen. Characters don't fall in love just because the plot wants it, but the love really feels real and deserved

+This show really hits hard the whole morals thing. However, even though there are times when the main character says he won't play the game and kill people, he doesn't just live by that and take whatever comes at him, but instead, if someone tries to blow him up, he'll actually fight back and will kill them.

+The touching moments of trust and emotion really stand out in this explosive world


Negatives:

-Only a 12 episode show (gimme more)

-Some scenes of torture and rape (just a warning in case you aren't into that)

-Characters, especially the main one, are SO naive it hurts sometimes


If you're really into theses shows where characters are put in the worlds of their favorite game, I highly recommend this show. In fact, I recommend it even you don't like those shows because it stands out from those other contenders. It ignores fanatsy in favor of real, deep meaning to the game and the morals one faces and how far into a game one can go before they lose themselves. If you want a touching, yet action-packed, violence-filled, explosive adventure, Btooom! is the perfect show

And that's why Btooom! gets a 9/10

I was looking for an anime with a post-adolescent protagonist and a serious storyline, and that brought me to Btooom! But the stats for this anime on ANN and MAL weren't outstanding, so I went into it with mixed feelings but came out impressed.
[NO SPOILERS]
OVERALL: 7/10
This anime is a good eye-candy that has a respectable story with interesting characters. If you’re into the action, sci-fi and survival game subgenres mixed with some romance, then you will enjoy this anime. This is one of those few examples where a decent-to-good manga is adapted into a better finished product.
STORY: 7/10
The story, in a nutshell, explores how people“survive” when forced into a harsh survival game in a tropical island in the middle of nowhere, and then it mixes this setup with some heavy action and light romance.


This anime quickly reminds of Sword Art Online (SAO), as they both share similar premises of a survival game; although SAO features a visual reality, whereas this anime is a real reality. The inciting incident of this anime also has a very similar feel to that of SAO. But pretty much everything else about this anime differs from SAO. 


The first episode should thrill you enough to get you very interested. The last episode warrants a second season to tie up loose ends. And everything in between is predictable but also enjoyable because the action-packed, raw adventure of the main characters will firmly hold your interest throughout the series.


CHARACTERS: 6/10


The male protagonist Ryouta Sakamoto had the privilege to undergo full development – he is very much human with his carnal tendencies balancing his natural virtue – but not without major faults. Ryouta for some reason always figured out stuff 100 years late. It would've made for a good plot point if the anime creators had set him up as a downright idiot,  but he wasn't established as one. In fact, on the contrary he was introduced as a gaming genius. By halfway into the series, it became clear that the anime creators spontaneously nerf his reasoning ability in certain scenes just to make the plot thicker and hike up suspense. Terrible idea.


The female protagonist Himiko was also well developed as a damsel in distress, and was at least not another archetypal useless female protagonist. She might not have been the super strong, super smart type, but she at least decisively pushed the story forward, considering that the premise of her strange interpersonal attitude was properly justified with a believable back-story.


The other characters represent a full spectrum of personalities and disorders: the psychopathic young teen, the treacherous doctor, the darwinistic thug who believes that only the fittest should survive, the pragmatic opportunist, etc. They probably won’t bore you.


ANIMATION & ART: 7/10


The art was neat, colourful and shiny; and since most of the scenes were outdoor, you have sunshine, and the anime creators effectuated its effect very well with the shadings and glitters. You can expect no less from the studio Madhouse.


Somehow the animation failed to fully convey the emotions that characters were expressing due to the subpar portrayal of subtle facial and bodily movements. This was a persistent flaw. The flow of motion during action scenes were decent enough to suffice. In all, the neatness and lustre of the art makes up for any shortcomings in animation, which were not even close to bad.


PLOT & PACING:


The plotline is non-linear in the first few episodes, with long flashbacks that, if consolidated, can span up to half of an episode. These flashbacks get in the way because many times they have absolutely nothing to do with the scene they interrupt. Nothing kills the mood more than having a flashback of "the girls’ day out" that interrupts the scene where someone’s throat has just been slit and sh*t is about to go down, especially when this flashback adds no value to the intense scene it just interrupted. However those flashbacks later on proved to be very useful to the story and eventually became very much appreciated. Nevertheless, they could have been spliced in more seamlessly; but really, they didn't have any overall adverse effect in the long-term.


The anime’s pacing was perfect. It didn't feel slow or rushed. Something intense always happened and moved the story forward in each episode.


PLOT ARMOUR:


The male protagonist Ryouta Sakamoto is equipped with a strong plot armour, literally. His skin had to be made of steel for him to survive some things other characters cannot (and did not) survive. But it wasn't rampant enough to detract from the fun.


FANSERVICE & ECCHI:


This anime abounds with bouncing clothed boobs, panty-shots and cleavages but no nudity; although there are scenes where the sexual tension is palpable and non-consensual sex implied. In all, there is a hefty dose of fan service in this anime, but it is more sanitized than in the manga.

[May contain slight spoilers]
BTOOOM!, a psychological-action-thriller series which was not only one of my first anime I had watched, but after 3 full watches, still remains one of my favourites and defiantly one of the better series I have watched. Although not having a horrible score on this site, I still do believe it to be severely underrated and I feel people focus on the negatives (of which it does have a couple) a lot more and ignoring the positives of which it does so well. 
Story
The story takes the basic concept of such manga as Battle Royale and adapts upon it, although having quitea few similarities I feel it does enough to become its own entity rather than a clone. Giving the 'players' different types of bomb (or BIM) and a radar to tactically take down their enemies and use strategies some of the players have learnt from playing the fictional video game 'BTOOOM!'. Also having the players being 'chosen' indivually through sign ups rather than completly random people adds another layer of characterization and originality. Being only 12 episodes, it has a lot of plot to fit into that length (50 chapters or so) so it does feel slightly rushed, I think it would have been alot better suited to a 24 episode series to flesh out the characters a bit more but for a 12 ep series, I deem it one of, if not the best.

[Overall 9/10]


Characters

For a 12 ep series, this has a lot of character development and back stories for most, if not all of the recurring characters, fed slowly in-between the current story, which does not feel forced and develops the backstory in segments, revealing more and more of the characters. This anime's strongest point and what it does the best or certainly on par with is the character's morales, and how in a desperate situation without law, your inner instincts come out and take over, be it murder, torture, rape etc. I feel that Himiko's character was extremely well developed and definitely the best character in the show imo, being a character that underwent a serious traumatic event and losing all trust in men became interesting when she met Sakamoto and her slowly regrowing that trust was fascinating to see. Some of the supporting characters seemed a little cliche therefore not getting a perfect rating.

[Overall 9/10]


Execution

Something that most people probably wouldn't rate an anime for but I deem to be one of the most important parts, how well executed was the anime, could it have been better? I believe this anime to be excellently executed, a fantastic mix of plot, character development and action, one of it's best features is how well it creates atmosphere and threat, at any moments the characters could be killed or attacked, and the great sfx and music add to this also.

[Overall 9/10]


Sound

Music - This anime has a very varied and decent soundtrack, not one I would rate as one of the best, but some tracks are sure to be memorable and stand out, most add to the atmosphere of the moment whereas a couple feel out of place. 

4/5

Voice Acting [Dub]

I'll start by saying Brittney Karbowski as Himiko did an exceptional job, one of the best female performances in anime imo, completely bought that character to life and cemented her as one of my favourite characters and voice actors overall. The rest of the cast stand in her shadow but only a couple felt a bit poor compared, most of them were at least good, but not too many other excellent performances.

4/5

[Overall 8/10]


Art

Not much I can say about the art, it is neither poor neither outstanding, I thought it did blood very well but overall good art, won't blow you away but will not be disappointing.

[Overall 8/10]


Enjoyment

As you might be able to tell I very much enjoyed this anime, partly because it was one of the first I had watched so I might be slightly biased, but after re-watching it twice and looking at it more critically rather than nostalgically I still very much enjoy this series and will remain one of my favourites, all 3 times I watched in 1 sitting because of it's excellent job of cliffhangers at the end of each episode, make it very hard to stop watching, only can say the same for ERASED, Steins;Gate and Death Note that also did that.

[Overall 10/10]


Overall Positives and Negatives

++Himiko

++Portrayal of character morales and trust

+Interesting take on the 'Battle Royale' genre

+Character development and backstories

+Overall sound

+Threat/atmosphere

+Told through multiple perspectives

+Learning the rules of the game felt believable, not genius nor stupid

+Cliffhangers


--Everyone is almost indestructible, many characters have BIM's explode right next to them and they just brush it off, I understand you can't really have an action series like this and have it 100% realistic, but they could have toned it down a bit.

-Unbelievable coincidences, there are too many characters that meet that knew in the real world, out of ~30 players out of millions in Japan this felt a little too coincidental, I could believe one but there are multiple characters who know others already, especially a certain in-game couple.

-Length, not exactly the anime's fault but a slightly longer series would have benefited it massively

-A certain ecchi BIM scene involving a Ms. Himiko, just felt stupid and out of place, completely unneeded and frustrating, also a couple other ecchi scenes seemed a little ott although some were used very well to the story's advantage.


OVERALL:

Enjoyment of the series as a whole: 9.7

Raw Quality of the series: 9.1

Overall Rating 9.4/10 : Exceptional series, just falling short of masterpiece status with a few too many negatives and short length.

Take 1/2 LOST, add 1/4 Gantz and spice it with Mirai Nikki. Dish out with beautiful tropical landscapes and you will get Btooom!
Short story long, Btooom! is another anime that features a mysterious survival game in which much like in Mirai Nikki the players are meant to eliminate competition in order to survive. Or they could work together to achieve better results and together figure out what brought them all on a beautiful deserted island. What's more, what they have to do in reality is very close to the gameplay of a popular video/computer game called Btooom!
Plot. In all honesty the plot is quite intriguingand yes it did remind me of LOST somewhat. In the beginning there's a lot of mystery as to what brings the protagonists here, how many players there are out here, who's behind this massive kidnapping and much more. The "gameplay" concept of this anime is also very cool; simple and effective. As the story goes, a lot of questions will get their answers though don't expect absolutely shocking plot twists. Most of the episodes will leave you thrilled because action scenes are rather satisfying.


Art. The art is very good. Beautiful tropical island reminds me the fresh screens from Far Cry 3. The landscapes are lovingly detailed and there are great light/shadow effects. Characters are decently designed and overall are pleasant to the eye. Animation quality is very good, movements are smooth and life-like.


Sound. The OP is wonderful with upbeat rhythm and sweet animations. It fits just right to an action-filled anime. The ED is traditionally much more soothing and gentle, more instrumental too.


Characters. This is probably the weakest point as of yet, though definitely it doesn't ruin the anime considering that there should be second season down the road.  Ryouta, the main protagonist, will probably get on your nerves quite a bit. His backstory unveils that he used to be a complete gaming junkie with no ambitions and goals and no regards to his family. Of course he will get to regret it all and repent his ways, but that's not my issue with him. My issue with him is his surprisingly "shounen" ideology of getting through such a grueling experience with his hands unstained, which is too naive and doesn't quite fit well into seinen aura this anime has. Sadly he doesn't change in that regard even by the end of the season and displays quite a number of such childish fits.

Another source of disappointment would be Himiko, a necessary set of nipples in this anime. Her backstory reveals several rape attempts and her struggle for survival. It's honestly quite expected that she'd act hostile towards male characters, still she comes around way too slow before even acting civil. The biggest letdown is that before she meets the main guy, she's perfectly able to stand up for herself, yet after the meeting she is reduced to a typically helpless big-boobed female which worships her hero (= read damsel in distress). Oh yeah speaking of boobs, they actually did a scene when a bomb ricochets off Himiko's. Glorious, isn't it.


Regardless, the relationships between the characters are taken slowly and steadily which is a big fat plus because it adds more realism and prepares good base for further episodes.


Overall, it's a very decent anime that combines nicely both action and suspense and does a good job portraying relationships and mind states of people in extreme situations. It's definitely better than similar survival titles like Mirai Nikki or Deadman Wonderland. This season completed, I'm actually looking forward to see the continuation.

Uninspired. The story follows every "fight each other on an island" trope in the book. The animation is average at best, though character designs leave something to be desired. The blonde haired lead protagonist is only there so that the main character can get his dick sucked for love and really, if I wanted to see that I'd be watching a different kind of anime. To me, she feels like a self insert for this new wave of feminism that thinks every man wants to rape them. I got told this anime was supposed to be for adults, yet it tries to force rape, murderand video games down my throat every single episode like a fifteen year old boy writing fan fiction for a Quentin Tarintino film.

I was a little hesitant with the anime, as I had just finished Sword Art Online, and was hoping it would not just be a simple copy. I can say that I was very surprised and even a little upset that the story ended, as I wanted more.
Story: This story is fantastic, and although the plot idea is rather popular, this anime does a great job of being unique. The thing that sets this one apart from the other for me is the dark mood to it. Btoom! is dark and revolves around Himiko and Ryouta, who face hard and dark pasts as well asthe morbid world they are tossed into.


Art:I thought the anime was rather beautiful. Great animations, vivd colors and nice explosions.


Sound: The music was good, but nothing too special. 


Character: I loved the characters in this story. Each had some strengths and weaknesses. Each character also had strong motives. The main characters all had reason for needing to survive, which fueled their actions in the story. The motives mostly were dark, and the feelings seemed to be rather dark and sad.


Enjoyment: Loved this show. Marathon'd it and have no regrets. Was an awesome watch, and I simply wish there was more!

SUMMARY REVIEW: This shit is ass. Don't watch it.
FULL REVIEW:
-Story 3 : The story could've been SOOO much better, this show had a good concept, it could've been a masterpiece if they gave a fuck about the series but it seems they cared more about catering to that average "pervy 12 year old" audience. But in 2018 this anime is 5 years old so I have to cut it some slack.
-Art 4: The artwork was average, nothing crazy, nothing ugly, its just ok. Killing people with only Explosions was the main reason I wanted to watch it but they all look the same. 
-Sound6:Everything audio-wise sounded good except the explosions and the music, which disappointed me. Oh and the dub is horrible so just go with the sub if you plan on watching it.\n\n
-Character 2: Oh shit this was baaaad. Lets get the worse character out the way: Himiko, Her as a character, she was useless unless her tits where on screen she was just a fantasy dream girl that would please the audience this show was going for. Her nearly being rape every other episode was just fucking disturbing for no reason. It was just there to, again, please the stupid audience. I didn't care for ANY of the characters. Why? Because their development was rushed. They really don't give us any background knowledge of the characters other than the reason why they were cast to the island. (I'm not saying that every character has to have a tragic past to have a watcher care for a character but it was the only thing this show had to build character) Sakamoto is the same character as Kirito from SAO: He's a clueless pervy nerd who is good at the game because he was good at the digital game. If you think about it Sakamoto should be dead, (if was dead it would've made this show 10x better because, it would show that nobody's safe and that anybody can die) as a NEET that plays games 24/7  he doesn't have any real physical or mental advantage. The ONLY advantage he has is that he knows all the BIMS and what they can do. Other than that he's not smart or clever or charming or anything. He was just good at the digital game. The first enemy Sakamoto faced should've killed him 5 times already, he was fit, knew how his BIMS worked and he was prepared to kill. But since Sakamoto was good a clicking a mouse he beat him....I don't want to talk about the others characters but here's a small summary: boring.\n\n
-Enjoyment 1: I think you know what I was gonna say.\n\n
-Overall 2: If they really cared about this series they'd gave the show more thought and more time to develop but they just wanted to make a quick buck instead of a masterpiece. I really wish this show was better but it's not so suck a dick

Btooom! 
This was a good anime with a pretty decent premise. I enjoyed watching it, and I could probably watch it again if I wanted to. However, this really isn’t the best of the all of the survival game animes out there. And this anime probably could have been better if it weren’t for a few things.
Story: 6.5/10
With survival games being so damn popular and so overdone, you really need to do something new with it if you want to make it into something special. Sure, having a bunch of people who have earned the hate of people they know be nominatedfor a deadly survival game is a great idea, but what’s the point of such a large cast if you’re not going to do anything with all of them. I hardly know anything about most of the characters and I REALLY, REALLY wanted to learn more about them! Like there was this one kid who liked to kill for fun. He didn’t care about life and would snap at any adult who tried to talk sense into him. He was very interesting and I wanted to see more of him. I wanted more insight into what he was thinking and I would’ve wanted to see a little more of his past. I also wanted to know more about Ryouta’s family so I could understand better where things went wrong. Also it may just be me, but it seemed like halfway through the show, they changed the rules on when you can use the bombs so I got kind of confused at some point. It also amazed me how quickly the two leads forgot about their comrade just for the sake of fanservice. They also ended it in a terrible way. The people who made the game claim that there is wrong with the island that the nominees are playing on, and then they just end it there. I wanted to know what was wrong with the island. I wanted more insight on the characters. You see, this is the problem with twelve episode series. FEW stories can be fully told in just 12 episodes! I wish they would’ve provided an explanation of some sort or actually went through with making a second season. So much build up, and yet so much letdown.




Animation: 7.5/10




The character designs were all very interesting and unique. I liked all of them. However, sometimes the background seemed really blurry. I’m not sure if this was done on purpose or not. Anyway, all of the fights scenes were done well and were pretty exciting.




Sound: 8/10




Not much to say here except that all the characters sounded great. I will say however, that this was my first time hearing the voice of Kanata Hongo (Ryouta’s seiyuu) and he sound really cool! They should really give him more roles in more anime. I think that the kid who liked to kill for fun sounded a little older than he probably should have, but it didn’t bother me that much. Besides that, the opening and ending themes were good.




Characters: 8.5/10




Whenever a new character wasn’t being introduced or returning for another appearance, Ryouta was pretty much responsible for holding the show up. He was a very likeable guy who spoke out when he disagreed with something and made good plans and stuck with them. He also had some really great character development. I liked him a lot, he was very relatable and I was rooting for him the whole time. Unfortunately, Himiko was pretty bland most of the time. She never really did anything helpful and just needed to be rescued most of the time. And when she was rescued, she was usually very ungrateful. Of course, all of this was blamed on her androphobia. Now, she has a perfectly good reason for her androphobia but for whatever reason, they liked to pass it off as humor. There would be scenes were Ryouta would ACCIDENTLY see her naked and she would go all Louise from Zero no Tsukaima and Taiga from Toradora! on him! And I would just stare at the screen and go REALLY?!?!? REALLY?!?!?! CAN’T YOU GUYS TAKE THIS A LITTLE SERIOUSLY?!?!?!? NUDITY IS NOT ALWAYS FUNNY AND BESIDES, HIMIKO KNEW IT WAS AN ACCIDENT!!! SO KNOCK IT OFF!! Anyway, besides the kill-loving kid, I also liked the lawyer, the defense force officer, and the doctor. There were other interesting characters too but I won’t talk about them here. But, I will say that they all deserved more screen time.




Overall: 7.5/10




This really was a good show, but it is in desperate need of a second season.

Ever since Battle Royale perfected the psychological narrative of humans being forced to kill other humans, it seems inevtiable that stories similar to it will appear, and while it certainly has its differences, Btooom! suffers from a lack of a second season (as per my knowledge), as the ending comes abruptly leaving viewers wanting a little bit more. 
As a concept, the story is actually very interesting. Rather than just have people being sent to an island at random to kill each other, the entire concept is that the contestants are playing, and actively balancing a game against their will. Confrontations are just about lifeand death, they are more along the lines of strategically figuring out how to defeat different opponents. As long as you turn off your inner critic, you can ignore the subtle plot holes that would ruin the action packed story. What really drives Btooom! is the reason why these particular people were sent to the island. Random people were given a letter in the mail asking if they wanted anyone to disappear. Naturally, there are both those who deserve the punishment, and those who do not. That alone made me curious about every character that was encountered. And of course, you have the typical tension of whether or not the players are going to betray each other or not. Unlike Battle Royale, in Btooom! there is the possibility of teaming up and actually winning. 


I did not really notice anything peculiar about the art or the sound, which makes me believe it was good, otherwise I'd complain about it. The character models and the scenery fit, and nothing seems out of place or obscure. 


The biggest variable in whether or not you'll enjoy Btooom! stems from its characters. Ryouta Sakamoto, our main protagonist, may have been a douche to his mother, but what we discover is that he really is a nice guy. Not only that, but as the series progresses, he really finds out about himself, and what he did wrong in life. He truly benefits from the whole ordeal. Some of the antagonists are curious subjects as well, but may come off as a bit cliche: "The hardened criminal who does whatever it takes to win", "the traitor who acts nice but is really waiting for the chance to strike", and of course, "the demented, insane character who wants to see people die for no reason". 


Yet, the biggest offense comes in the form of the female lead, Himiko. While her back story is interesting, her insecurities paint her as a stereotypical girl who cannot fend for herself or think for herself, and often breaks down into tears. From a narrative standpoint, the gig gets old pretty fast. At one point I shouted, "come on! Just do something, anything!" to no avail. No doubt this is Ryouta's show, and nobody is going to steal it from him. 


All in all, I thought it was enjoyable only for the premise. I had read bits and pieces of the manga, and after seeing the end of the anime, I'm curious to see how far along it is. If it ever gets a second season, my opinion of it may improve. Still, if you are looking for something action packed, with a great plot, Btooom! might be a good fit... just don't expect much out of the female lead.

Btooom! Successfully combines a cast of characters and situations that while not necessarily unique or new are exciting when placed together.
30-40 people are "kidnapped" and dropped on a deserted island with nothing but the clothes on their back and a fanny pack of bombs. In addition they've had a chip implanted into their hand that allows them to "sense" other players and is only removable if they're dead. They are told that the only way off the island is to collect seven additional chips (or basically to kill seven people).
Each person then deals with this in their ownway, forming alliances, going alone, betrayal, traps, hiding, actively hunting, running, etc. They are "aided" by airdrops of food, water, and other supplies but these are limited and often lead to major fights. Additionally, they must contend with komodo dragons, starvation, thirst, injury, lack of sleep, and stress.


As the story progresses we learn that each person was sent here by someone close to them that wanted them gone and that each character has a troubled past of some sort or another. Enough backstory is given to genuinely care about each charter but not bog the greater story line down.


The art style isn't anything new but is generally nice to look at and works well. Character designs are predictable to some extent, that is personalities match what would generally be expected from different appearances and it's not to difficult to predict what order people will die in. The opening theme songs are kind of angsty but worth multiple listens. I would consider the genre to be mostly action with a little bit of drama/romance. There's a couple of sad moments but they're normally followed by more action so there's no time to dwell on them.


It's easy enough to follow that it can be a light watch but also has enough moral/ethical/situational dilemmas for greater thought and discussion. I look forward to a second season but could be decently satisfied with this season's ending being the end.

Let's talk about Btooom!
I know, maybe it's not a very good name but fairly well defined since the anime is based on bombs and explosions.
It is an anime released in 2012, which consists of 1 single season of 12 episodes. It is based on a manga released in 2009 but continues to publish at a rate slow enough (once a month).
Within the genres we can emphasize action, science fiction and a certain romance to be clarified with the progress of anime.
HISTORY:
Btooom! It is a popular online game based on pumps. Its main objective is to devise strategies with teams and with different types of pumpsto win the game.\n
Sakamoto, our main protagonist, is one of the best players in the world of this game. In turn, it is a boy of 22 who neither study nor work and spends all day in his room playing until one day he wakes up hanging from a parachute on a seemingly deserted island without knowing why.\n
Here begins the real adventure, because a "organización'' has kidnapped several people and has led to this island, including the main character, and gave them a bag of bombs and a" radar'' (chip embedded in hand ) each, just as in the game Btooom! ...\n
This organization has kidnapped people who have been "nominadas'' by others who apparently hated them for some reason, so that all people of the island have been bad people with someone or something.\n
So if you want to escape from this island they have a total of 8 chips, so you have to kill at least 7 people.\n
Sakamoto will find a wide variety of people, including a girl I used to play online but most of all a lot of people who want to kill to survive.\n\n
MAIN CHARACTERS\n
-Ryōta Sakamoto: Ryōta of 22 years is the main male protagonist of the series. He is an elite player in Btooom! 4 stars (the scale is with a maximum of five stars) who was nominated by his mother, to participate in the game Btooom! In real life.\n
He was often seen as being abusive to his mother and stepfather while trying to motivate him to present several works that were getting to him, none of whom he wanted and considered his unnecessary interference. This is because he had set his sights on a job in Tyrannos Japan, a group of game developers who created Btooom!.\n
-Himiko: The female protagonist of the series. She is in love with Ryota and married him in the game Btooom!. She was nominated by his group of ex-girlfriends because together attended a group meeting with a group of celebrities who ended up raping them, this only Himiko, who was delayed and after arriving and finding out what was happening was saved fled to bring police however her friends not only believed guilty of this misfortune, also they preferred to think it was an accomplice of rapists.\n
At the beginning she hated men for the incident with her friends, because after reaching the island the first group that had belonged problems.\n
When she meets Ryota this shows that will protect her while alive. Either way, still maintain some distance between them due to insecurity.\n\n
Art\n
In many characters we see a pretty bad design.\n
In the case of Himiko, whose facial design is quite simple and a little weird.\n
In other characters we find a better design but the fact that the two players have a simple design gives a negative point to the anime.\n
And now comes the most awaited moment ...... THE OPPAIS. Well, Btooom! only gonna get big breasts of the protagonist, which are practically the only ones throughout the anime but not fall short.\n
Btooom! It has a good animation. We can highlight the great animation of the explosion, which is the basis of virtually anime.\n
Also the sound and animation when using the radar is pretty well animated, and all chases through the jungle and old buildings is more than good.\n\n
MUSIC\n
In music I can say that is quite well suited to every moment of the anime, which is usually quite normal in animes of this style.\n
Characterized mainly by the action music in times of struggle and ambient music in times of stress.\n\n
ENJOYMENT\n
At first I resent the slow development of the anime and naivete of the protagonist, but as was advancing the anime, the plot became more interesting and Sakamoto finally showed his great talent.\n
For me, it was a pretty good picture that includes an original idea that is being based on bombs, but has lacked something that would make were glued to the screen. Something more epic moments of tension or would have been quite favorable.

Btooom! An anime with so many qualities but so many defects at the same time there is not much to talk about it but the feeling of something "missing" this anime suffers from it and is something remarkable after its end, its story is good and to some extent original "People sent to an island to kill themselves with bombs" a premise up to different ..... speaking so you can even try to guess how the anime will unfold though he does a great job of not let things repetitive as he expects Until it arrests to you in several moments but they lack thingsin him as previously said more development of the (secondary) characters, clarifications and most important an end ...... as many know the anime does not have a closed end or even satisfactory it finishes in A KEY scene of the story, the lack of one or two episodes really made a difference, the anime ended in a climax leaving you looking at the screen saying "is it over?" And it is not only this several outstanding issues MANY and this comes to give discouragement in the end because ..... well .... is missing much thing (not to mention the excessive exploitation of the body of the main female persong), taking it out the anime Technically is well done (for the time) soundtrack very good, traits even that pretty (mad house) .... in general is a very good anime but only watch if you do not care about open ends or if you leave for manga ( Which by the way did not read) ... despite its defects is an anime that manages to entertain you and very well leaving you tied up however in the end all this expectation created by the anime is not supplied what much influence in its final impression on the series

Um... okay then. This was... eventful? I mean, it wasn't bad. But it wasn't astounding either. However, it had enough action in it to hold my attention the whole time, which is a feat by itself (lately I've had the attention span of a goldfish). 
The story was fine, though with the shortness of the series and the many plot points that they had to cover, they ended up not getting to even explore all the possible plot lines they could. It was also very predictable. 
The art was pretty good, but nothing remarkable. It seemed that everyone except the 'gorgeous' heroine was drawn well,ironically. I had many problems with her design, but I can't put my finger on it. 


The explosion sounds and the voiceacting was decent for most of the characters, except for Himiko, again. The songs were amazing. 


The characters were almost good. I know that sounds rude, but the thing is that every character had so much potential, but it was somewhat wasted. Each had a backstory and a life, that much was for sure, but the backgrounds weren't very well explored. Even the main character's background was only explored briefly in the last episode. Some of the characters could have been very fleshed out and entertaining, but it never happened. 


I enjoyed most of it overall. 


Would I watch it again? 

Probably not. It was good enough the first time around, but when you already know what's going to happen and there's that many plot holes and no ending, there isn't any motivation to rewatch it. 


Would I recommend it?

If you like explosions and hot girls pairing up with gamer guys and some light explosion gore, sure. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND IF YOU DO NOT LIKE UNFINISHED STORIES, GAMING, BLOOD, BOMBS, ETC. 


I would like to say that this looks like it was inspired by Sword Art Online though. 


Anyways, have a nice day everyone!

(Don't worry, this review is spoiler free)
Story 6/10: The story is a good run of the mill survival game. Although now a days, that's not a very creative plot they added their own little spark that other survival anime series don't have. 
Art 5/10: Art wise is very interesting. After watching series like Higurashi No Naku Koro Ni and Sword Art Online, the art style is quite different and most certainly stands out. However other than Btooom! is animated in a different way, it doesn't have anything special that stands out about the art.
Sound 6/10: I personally think that one of the best things aboutthis series is the soundtrack AND ESPECIALLY DAT OPENING!


Character 4/10: I think the characters are very boring and over used. The main character is a sterotypical heroine that has no interesting personality. The love interest is annoying claiming that because of her past that every man in the world is awful and lewd. As a matter of fact, I think the characters with the MOST character would be background characters that we rarely see. 


Enjoyment 5/10: Personally, I enjoyed watching this series! Until the end. I personally think that the creators we're just too lazy to write a proper ending. Because there is too much potential adventure to happen for it to end. Granted, this would be a perfect ending for the end of season two, then later have a season three. However it's been 4 years. They lost the interest of it's viewers.


Overall: 5/10: This series wasn't really my cup of tea. I didn't enjoy it as much as people said I would. But I think anyone who is reading this (Who hasn't seen the series already) should watch Btooom! to learn what a mediocre at best series looks like.
