Bomberman meets Halo?
Haha, this anime is very good I have no complaints about it. It was very well executed and it has its own originality to some extent.
Everything from the story to the soundtrack was very well executed. It very well deserves a Season 2 and the wait will be definitely worth it!
-Story: If you liked the movie 'Predators' this is a lot similar in the sense that a bunch of people got kidnapped and sent in a tropical scenery and are involved in a survival game. Except they're killing each other and not hunted. It was well thought and made sure to not missdetails. It was also very well executed in the sense that the plot twists weren't something too impossible.


-Art: A1 Pictures have never failed to amaze me with their art-style. The character designs are very good including the in-game Btooom! avatars.


-Sound: The soundtrack is very good and very fitting to the atmosphere. It's not too distracting while still keeping the intensity.


-Character: Anime including MCs being really good at games tend to make the MC really pathetic and annoying. Though this isn't the case with Sakamoto. He has very good intuition, a skilled strategist and knows what he's doing. I'm also a fan of MCs going insane from time to time so this is definitely a plus.


Overall from the first to the last episode I really enjoyed this series. I'll be looking forward to a Season 2 and I'm sure it will be as good as this.

Btooom!.
Story: 8/10
It's underrated, exemplary and stylish. The storyline of this anime is fast-paced, and the lead character is immediately thrown into the death game. It's a combination of SOA and battle royale, although with less action and more grenades. It's really easy to understand and appreciate the story, and you will get hooked after the first few episodes.
Art: 8/10
The art is by all means not the greatest, but there is some brilliant art work at times. The various environments are well done.
Sound: 8/10
The sound is well-done, with a catchy theme song and general interesting soundtrack. It's not the best, but definitely enough to not putyou off.\n\n
Character: 7/10\n\n
During the anime there is a limited number of characters, mainly because of the fact the majority of it takes place on an isolated island. This leads to you being attracted to some of the main characters, although they're really not that interesting. Character development is generally weak at times and you barely get to know any more about the characters except some rushed explanations when it's necessary to advance the plot. Nevertheless, there is a diverse cast of characters; goodies and baddies who you will loathe and love. There's also a relationship between two characters which slowly blossoms as the story advances.\n\n
Enjoyment: 9/10\n\n
The anime's fast-paced nature and uncomplicated story means it's so accessible for anyone who likes any anime. There is some pretty interesting scenes with flashing lights, bombs and a range of unorthodox jungle creatures. If you're here for the romance then it's not for you; it's an anime about action, decisions and the bangs of bombs.\n\n
Overall: 8/10\n\n
While it's not the best anime out there, Btooom! deserves a shot. Whether you like psychological, romance or harem anime, this one is worth trying. It's addictive and will keep you interested. And though the ending may be disappointing, the mid-way action more than makes up for it.

Btooom! was a series that had a lot of potential, but in my opinion, did not deliver it as strongly as it could of.
This review will be to the point as much as possible
Story: The story was very similar to Mirai Nikki's that there is a group of people that have to fight to the death. in Btooom!, each person involved in the "game" gets an initial 8 bombs or "BIMs" and tries to kill 7 other people in order to leave the game and go back to their normal lives. The story was overall very good, it just didn't explain enough to the "whydid this happen?" factor

8/10


Art: The art was not fantastic for a newer anime because some of the explosions looked pretty bad. Also, on quite a few scenes, the characters' faces looked very awkward and poorly drawn. 

6/10


Sound: The first Opening is very good and goes well with the show. The second Opening does not hit me as "Wow this is really good!" because most of the scenes in the opening are just from previous episodes. Also, the BGM's were placed in at the wrong times. At least that's what I felt. The music just didn't really match the situation the characters were in. The Ending was also slightly above average.

7/10


Character: For sure the weakest part of the show. I didn't feel sympathetic for ANY of the characters shown nor did I feel they were in the series long enough. My favorite character, Kira had maybe 15 minutes of screen time. A lot of the characters only appeared for 3 minutes and we never see them again.

5/10


Enjoyment: Despite being fairly mediocre, I really enjoyed this series. I found it easy to marathon and you never were really bored with any scenes. The action was very good and I was always at the edge of my seat to see what type of BIM was thrown next. 

8/10


Overall thoughts: Btooom! is overall a good anime with some minor errors in each section, but nonetheless very entertaining. I would recommend this if you like Action shows, explosions, or you want to marathon a quick 12 episode anime. 

7/10


Finally, thank you for reading my review on Btooom! and have a great day! ^-^

Have you ever just sat down, watched an anime in one straight-shot and in the end came out feeling like you just watched something amazing? For me, Btooom! was one of those such animes.
Story: 9/10
The story itself was pretty good, mixing in suspense, suspicion, and an array of twists, and good character development, especially between Ryouta and Himiko. As far as I can tell, there haven't been many survival type animes that have come out of the industry, it's definitely something that's rather defining, or more importantly, it is something different than what normally gets put out each season. 
Art: 8/10 
The art style wasrather decent for the show, however I did feel that for a 2012 anime, it was lacking at times.


Sound: 9/10


I really enjoyed the opening and ending, and the various music that plays during the show.


Character: 9/10


As I stated before, the characters develop quite well. Due to the harsh conditions they all have to go through, nearly every character, both main and supporting go through some sort of development and they end up pretty different from when they are first introduced. What I feel is pretty defining for this anime, is how the characters begin to compare trust to survival and the two themes get put to test a lot during this show, friends become enemies and enemies become friends. Ryouka and Himiko both experience the above, especially when dealing with each other.


Enjoyment: 9/10


What I disliked the most about this anime, was how much it was overshadowed by Sword Art Online, but pretty much all animes that aired last fall were overshadowed by it. I will say right now, this is no SAO, in fact, this anime is more or less what SAO should have been. It was definitely a good watch and don't be turned off by it simply because it's most closely like SAO.


Overall: 9/10


I bought Far Cry 3 a few days before I started this anime, and I must say, between the combination of the two, it was a very good week. The themes of survival and deception appealed to me a lot at the time, and is probably the most influential aspect that one will take out of watching this particular show.

Ask yourself, What would you do if you woke up one day on a deserted island with nothing but your clothes, a pouch with eight Bombs in it, a weird green gem attached to your hand and now you are expected fight for your life to get off this island. This sums up the basic story of BTOOOM!
Our main character Ryouta Sakamoto is one of the best players in the world in the online game "BTOOOM!" where you are only allowed to fight with bombs. In real life Ryouta is a NEET who has a damage relationship with his family and has fled into thevirtual world of "BTOOOM!" where he is a celebrity and even has a girl friend.


But his world is turned upside down when he wakes up stuck in a parachute in a tree on a deserted island having lost his memories. This soon turns into a deadly game where you can trust nobody and your best friend is yourself. During the series he meets other people who also has been dropped onto the island along with him in his quest to get of this god forsaken island and figure who is behind this sinister game.


The art of this series is really quite good and it reminded my a bit about the art style from Death Note. The series was produced by studio madhouse which makes sense in that case.


The acting is really standard from anime in general and the soundtrack isn't really much to write home about. I'd say that the sound is the shows weakest part.


Another thing that stood out about this show was the characters who were all really well developed and everyone had at least some change done to their personalities over this 12 episode series. I'd say that the most enjoyable thing about watching "BTOOOM!" is seeing the characters changing over time and interacting with each other.


Overall I really enjoyed this show and I would recommend it to you if you like psychological action series or movies like Battle Royal.

In a industry filled with archetypes and plot formulas, few series of anime have the ability to really stand apart from the rest. Anything amazing seems to have already been done before and the characters start to become simple skin swaps of each other. Btooom! isn't a series that will break too many boundaries of the 'death game' sub genre, but it does a good job of not falling behind.
Btooom! is a story about a highschool gamer who wakes up on an island with a bag of bombs, a day's worth of supplies and a chip ingrained on his hand. This much can be foundfrom the synopsis. The story has a decent beginning, a great middle and a weak end. The action of the series is good, but interactions between characters, as well as back story flashbacks, tend to overshadow the action in terms of quality. The fighting is good, especially in the middle of the series, but near the end, it falls into a pattern: "impossible escape, fight back, another impossible escape, fight back". This pattern robbed the action of its suspense.  The ending seemed abrupt and since there not another episode after it to cushion the blow, it only makes it worse. The manga is still going on, so a sequel could help the series recover from this pitfall. 


The art in the series is great. The character designs fit the characters personalities and the animation is good too. Enviroments, while a bit redundant, help bring life to the battle scenes. 


The sound is the best I've heard in a while. The voice acting is spot on and the opening is fantastic. The sounds of explosions and other SEs are good too. The one fault I have is the ending. The music does not seem to fit with the series and its slow pace decompresses the adrenaline that the series thrives on. 


The characters of this series each had the potential to be great, but many of them had their spotlight taken off too soon. Due to the short length of the series, many foes the protagonists face only have about an episode or two of scene time before they disappear until the ending. It was especially sad because the villains are truly frightening. As far as the main cast goes, the protagonist has his on and off moments. One moment he is a level-head young man, the next he's a naive person who seems to have learned nothing from his time in the game. The female protagonist is much more consistent and she isn't only just eye candy. She has a believable personality and easily bucks the stereotypical 'dumb hot blonde'. The side characters are decent enough, with exception of a man named Taira. At first he seems like a well built character, but as the series progress, his presence seemed to only fill up time in the series, especially near the end. 


The enjoyment of the series depends on the viewer. Those who play online shooters and love leveling up in games like CoD will probably find more in this series than just the passive gamers, but the point is that this is an anime for gamers. If you hate FPSs, you probably will have hard time understanding some of the concepts of this anime and that may hinder your enjoyment. The memorable villains and heroine keep this series from falling into the decent bin, but due to the predictable ending, I won't recommend watching it again. 


Overall, this anime has a decent, albeit rushed story, nice art, great sound and solid characters. Would I watch it again? Probably not, but it wasn't a waste of time.

This is my first review so I hope you guys find this helpful
The story(8):
Lets make one thing clear at the start. This isn't an anime like Mirai Nikki were you are put in a virtual world and the main character is crying all over the place. This anime is in the real world and with a main character that is more mature in a view ways. He's name is Ryouta Sakamoto and he is ranked #10 in the world top player of the game Btooom!. That is a game were you need to kill other opponents with as you may have quest bomb's. He isdropped on an island for at that time reasons unknown and finds out that he needs to play Btooom! to survive. Every opponent has a bag with bombs and there are a view different types with each their own advantages. He finds himself in sticky situations and you can see him struggle in those situations. He finds a guy and they start running along together. They stick to getter and one of the strong points in the story is that they all feel like real people. They all don't trust other people but they won't kill each other to except of course some people that are just maniacs and start killing every one.  He later finds a girl with men issues. Her name is Himiko. Everything in the story is progressing very slowly and that is good for the character development in Btooom!. The only problem with Btooom! is the ending. I won't spoiler anything of course but it isn't done and season 2 won't be released because the sales in Japan weren't as great as expected. Nevertheless it is an awesome story were everything falls to place and if you want to know how it continues after the anime you should start reading the manga. Now Let's move on to the next topic.


The Animation (8):

The first thing you will notice is how   well the characters are drawn. It is not like the anime you know today and that is better. The lighting is done perfectly and when the action comes you won't see anything that will make you lose interest. Of course there are a view parts that could have drawn better like when he was playing Btooom! on he's xbox 720 or something and you could see some points that should have been better but those won't ruin anything. It could be that the game was just to badly developed that the xbox 720 couldn't handle it but yeah who cares. Well let's continue with:


The Sound (8):

The opening and ending song of btooom! were great, with the opening standing out more. They let you think you were on that island as well with the sounds and the music in the background went great with the scenes they were in.  There isn't much more I can say about the sound except it is well done so let's continue with:


The Characters (9) :

The character feel more alive than ever because they seem like real people. Ryouta Sakamoto is an 22 year old dude that likes to play Btooom! all day. He feels like an average student only he has some anger issues with he's family. He is selfish and thinks only how things effect him. He felled like he was the men in Btooom and that's why he played all day. As for Himiko she is an average popular beauty that just isn't having any luck. She has men issues for a reason and you feel sorry for her to the whole story. She was almost raped and it felled like she reacted to that as real as can be. She didn't turn into some kind of whore like in some echi anime's instead she fought to maintain her purity and that is something I like to see in an Anime. For some other character is in the anime there is enough background in Btooom to make you understand them. They pulled that of very well if you consider that this is an 12 episode anime.  


Overall:

Btooom is an anime I recommend to all of you. The story is great with the ending as a letdown but if you don't mind to read the manga later on you won't regret watching it. The character feel real and the sound and animation both make it better.  I give this anime a 8,5 out of 10.

This will be my first time to write a review. I hope it will be of good help because I was in state of mixed emotions upon finishing the series.
An acquaintance recommended this series to me because I am looking for some action/adventure genre at the moment, yes I was satisfied with it. At the same time, I saw it on the list of "20 most passionate anime kisses" here, so I fed my curiosity by downloading the series.
Anyway, at first, I thought it will be of the same genre like Mirai Nikki [Future Diary] Sword Art Online and No Game No Life because ofthe connection of reality/virtual world, I wasn't wrong. "If you like some characters with interesting backgrounds and detail you will like this anime."
Story:
Very well done story about people put on an island to kill one another and to escape you must kill a certain number to do so. This is not a traditional anime and does not appeal to anime fandom in any way. That is why I loved the detailed story. What many people fail to realize in "real life" including war, there are many people who do not act intelligent and carry out the violence their told too. Someone who is despised and not wanted especially act this way and itis not unbelievable that they would kill each other. Many say there is another way to escape rather than killing each other is a lie and refuse to face reality. That is why we have wars today! If you follow the story (with zero fillers :) I might add) with no expectations then you will be impressed I guarantee it! 


Art: 


Art is well done. Womens' face is more round and again does not follow traditional anime drawing. Overall very well done and distinguished.


Sound:


Excellent could not spot errors after watching it twice!


Character:


The protagonist is a boy who is a shut in who plays video games (Not much different from otakus) all day. Has no job. Pretty believable to me. If you think there are no people like him you are very wrong. Of course there people who really don't like him including his parents!  That's what leads him too the island! As I stated, good; detailed background with believable characters.


Enjoyment:


I re-watched this series so yes it is good. Just not great.


Overall:

I think a number of people who look this anime up, do not expect it much from it. I heard the name mentioned in a few forums and in my recs, so I wanted to check it out. After looking at the synopsis and genre tags, I thought at best this anime would come out as cookie cutter recreation of the past like fifteen shows I saw. Once I actually began to watch it, though, I totally threw out any preconceptions.
The plot itself seems simple at first, but still original. People trapped on an island and must survive by killing each other. But, they canonly use bombs. Kinda cool, okay. Typical action, right? Well, while I anticipated a relatively one-dimensional story, an intensive, almost Lord of the Flies-esque, scenario takes place. What happens to humans when their only obvious means for escape comes from the deaths of those around them: Survival of the fittest? Jungle Law? Or will they maybe, possibly, perhaps band together and overcome like an encouraging, believe-in-humanity story?


Btooom!delivers its plot realistically, which I think makes up one of the best points of this anime. This  series is not good versus evil or right versus wrong, it's humanity versus itself. No one gets heroized. Ain't no superman fighting fires for justice in this show. It's an intense ride and, although only a few integral themes present themselves and therefore seemed to get rehashed often, just for the story itself, I'd totally recommend this show. And that's kinda rare these days, no?


The art came out pretty well, nothing special really to say about it. The character styles seemed somewhat original. The background art was great, though, if you care about that. By the way, not as much ecchi as you might think. Actually, in terms of legitimate fan-service, it's pretty much non-existent.


The soundtrack fit the show well. I skipped the opening and ending most of the time, though haha. The in-show tracks, though, sounded good, but not like amazing or masterful. It was good enough to be good enough.


Btooom! made some very good characters with individualized personalities. The writers developed the characters fairly well and they drive the story. If you watch Btooom!, you're watching for the characters and the interactions between them.


All in all, unexpectedly awesome anime. Watch it, it's definitely worth it.

Story : 7/10
Btooom! takes you to a world that has been seen before in the world of anime, would it be from Sword Art Online or Mirai Nikki. It is really a mix of both and shares the same type of action/thriller feeling. Not much is said about how the Btooom! game works, however, which is one of the lacking points, in my opinion. One character can say that that's 'how it worked' in the game, but never will the user really see what was indeed the way to play, except for the first 2 minutes of the show. 
Art : 8/10
Btooom! really has anamazing scenery, but since it's on a deserted island, you get to see pretty much the same things over and over again. The characters are well drawn and the gore part of the anime is really well done (saying 'decomposed' should ring a bell here). 


Sound : 10/10


There is not much to say here. The explosions sounds are real, genuine and clearly well thought. The voices of the character all share their own personalities. 


Character : 6/10


Not much is impressive on this point on Btooom! The characters are plain, going from the classic-huge-cleavage-almost-got-raped-blond-girl to the guy-that-has-a-plan, we don't see much that is very well thought. Needless to say, the character development is pretty much absent. 


Enjoyment : 7/10


With only 12 episodes, it is hard not to enjoy Btooom!. The story goes fast and keeps you on a track for all twelve episodes. It is indeed pretty horrible to end on such an horrible note, however, with many questions left unanswered, which explains my grade on this category. 


Overall : 7/10


Btooom! has it's good points, nobody can deny it. The plot is twisted and some of the images are pretty horrible to watch, so you should be warned. It's easy to go through all twelve episodes in a day or two, so you don't have to plan ahead. Just start it when you feel like spending a nice time with a pretty nice story and some nice thrill, but don't expect much conclusion, because you won't get any!

Story: Starts off revolving around a NEET gamer which becomes really good at what he does as a NEET. Later he gets abducted and sent to an island to fight other people, a pretty decent story line enough to grab your attention.
Art: Looked pretty clean so it's good enough to watch to keep yourself entertained for a bit.
Sound: It sounded like what you'd expect/hear from playing an FPS with grenades and that type of stuff so it's good enough to pass.
Character: Similar to what you'd find in an average anime, white knight protagonist gets beat down stands back up. Gets a few allies along theway, nothing special.\n\n
Enjoyment: This part may seem very biased and is entirely my opinion but the anime was good all the way up to until the end , I couldn't believe it that one episode could ruin the entire anime. Mr. Protagonist is trying to be a good guy and he gets beat down (best example I could think of without spoiling the entire anime.) This made it very hard for me to enjoy the rest of the anime thinking how cliche it was , and it not only happens once but twice  and totally ruined it for me. \n\n
Overall: I recommend watching it ONLY if you're prepared for cliche scenes that are almost cringe worthy and if you're okay with the risk of getting cancer near the end.

This review will have no spoilers in it, however, I will be blunt in saying that the way this show ended, is very much like how Deadman Wonderland ended, which was that it ended with some resolution, but with TONS of questions left unanswered or things that were not ended that should have been ended.   Outside of that issue, the rest of this will be fairly postive.
Story:   Basically think of this as Survivor (the TV show) meets anime.   No seriously, that's what the plot revolves around which is people stranded on an island and they have to survive exceptthis time its a deadly form of survival where people can, and will, die.   The story description in the MAL page here describes it best.   IMO, the story was simple enough to follow yet interesting enough to continue.   Various conflicts would happen and it was enjoyable.   There are some scenes of sexual violence so if rape and implied rape makes you feel unease, then be warned that there are a few scenes early on, but you don't see the full act of it happening per se.



Outside of that, the story is basic and simple but that's not bad when compared to animes with stories so complex that you have to read wikia, the manga, online posts, or just rewatch it many times, just to understand it.



Art:    I swear I had this vibe that the art style for some scenes and some people were like SnK.   The style was fine.  Nothing in particular to say about it.  The people were interesting in looks, some had distinctive features like a large forehead (well it appears that way), braids, tats, mega breasts, etc.    And speaking boobs, the fanservice was surprisingly mild.  Sure the main female has nice DD or E cup breasts, but there was only a few fairly mild ecchi scenes, so the mood was kept fairly serious.



Sound:     Not much to say here.  The music OP and ED were great, BGM was fitting mostly.  Of course the use of Half Life Crowbar-hitting-metal sound was there a few times.



Character:    Weakest part of the show.  There were plenty of characters that COULD  have had more interesting things to them, but it was usually explained through flashbacks and would last for just one episode.    The main two characters were lacking in detail but at least they established how they were loosely connected before you find out later how they truly met.    



Enjoyment:   I really wanted to like this, I really did.  I found myself enjoying it from the near start, all the way to the end, but then when I saw the last few minutes of it, i realized that they were going to do a Deadman Wonderland move on me and end the show (and series) on a ton of cliffhangers and with many things left unanswered.    With that said, I don't know if I would recommend this to anyone because I would hate for them to watch it and then say "Wow, all that just for an ending that isn't an ending?".

Into anime you can (possibly) relate to due to it involving some guy/gal that spends their time playing games 24/7? Maybe even interested in moderate-large amounts of gore? Looks like you're looking at the right anime when it comes to Btooom! as they involve both of these things and many other things you could potentially be interested in.
I originally heard about Btooom! from a friend of mine whilst I was feeling somewhat bored one night, looking for a nice, gore-filled, psychological anime I could really get into and have fun with; Btooom! was the recommendation, as I've stated. I must say, it surpassed my expectationsto some point, but it wasn't exactly perfect yet I can't really say why because... well, spoilers.


Anyway, let's get down to the brass and review this anime!


Story - 7/10


A survival story is something I really enjoy, especially when there are bombs and a load of other people involved. One amazing thing about the story with this anime is that it isn't a simple case of "let's throw you into this place and see what happens"... although it actually is... let me rephrase that! The story focuses a lot on Ryouta, the 22-year-old who got thrown into this place and yet it focuses a lot on bonds made with other people and it does surprisingly have a lot of character progression, which is a must in an anime.


I'm not going to write much else about the story, but one little thing about the story which put me off is that I felt it was incredibly similar to the movie, "Condemned", turned into anime with a change of characters and with the use of bombs instead of pure survival. However, that's just me being picky, haha!


Art - 7/10


It may be a very, very weird comparison, but I feel that I enjoyed that art in this as much as I did with Highschool of the Dead in the sense that colours really stood out, meaning colours weren't pale and they didn't look bad. I don't know, it's hard to explain! Anyways, the way the art was done really made things such as the jungle look absolutely beautiful, and the animation was also incredibly well done. I unfortunately can't think about many negatives to the art, considering I'm not much of an artist myself and don't know what's great and what's awful.


Sound - 8/10


I have a certain policy when it comes to watching a new anime, and that is that I must always, always listen to the opening and the ending at least once, even when it changes. It's thanks to this policy that I ended up enjoying the opening and ending to Btooom! and I was able to bask in the glory of such sound.


Along with this, the voice actors / actresses used in Btooom! were pretty damn cool, as all of them seemed to fit their counterparts pretty well and helped me to feel a little more involved in their world, such examples being Kira Kousuke, a psychotic brat who was actually cool who ended up having a voice actress that sounded pretty psychotic when needed; nice going on really getting the good people to fill out the spots!


Character - 5/10


Unfortunately, this is going to have the lowest score for me and I don't like to give low scores, as you can probably tell. The characters were incredibly predictable which ruined all of the fun with absolutely everything. Ryouta was made to be smart from episode 1, and he was way too smart for my liking whereas Himiko was your typical little girl that had to have somebody to depend upon all of the time. Honestly, the characters could have been done much better.


Enjoyment - 7/10


Despite the let down that are the typical character personalities, the show was very enjoyable for  me as I certainly found what I wanted in the psychological department along with the gore department. I was really indulged in this anime from start to end and wouldn't mind watching it again if I could be bothered. Shame there's no second season though...


Overall - 7/10


In my own personal opinion, Btooom! was a good piece of work which was very enticing, leaving me wanting more and more with no hope as it's not going to happen. I certainly recommend it if you enjoy gore and a smartass character, especially when he's got some hopeless girl to handle, haha! It's good for the story though as well, so check it out.



Forgive me if this is way too long for you, as this is my first review and I wasn't entirely sure how much I should do or about how I truly, truly, TRULY felt about each little section. However, this is most likely what I'd stick with no matter what, unless I decided to go through and write my review whilst I'm watching each episode, changing it after each episode until I had the final piece... which is definitely not happening.


Hope you enjoyed, and if you do watch Btooom!, ENJOY IT!

Btooom has been on my watch list for some time and finally got round to watching it. Its a story of a guy  Ryouta who’s a bit of a looser in real life but excellent at the game Btooom. One day he wakes up and finds that he’s been left on an island and is actually stuck in a real life game. Unlike other anime’s where people are stuck in a virtual world, the island is very real as are those who want to kill you. It’s easy to see what’s influenced Btooom with elements of Lost, the Hunger games & lord of theflies all present here.


Ryouta must soon learn to use his skills in Btoom to survive. Each player has a chip embedded in their hand which acts as a sonar. In order to get off the island you must collect eight chips. This is the main motivation of characters in the series.  


The characters in Btoom are its weakest aspect. Ryouta soon meets Himiko a female player who for all purposes is not a very good player and is one of the weakest female characters I’ve seen in some time. She is constantly in danger from being raped, blown up or tortured. The rape theme in particular is quite unwelcome and sets the serious tone for the series and a touch of humour is sadly lacking. The side characters are mostly very unpleasant. They also turn on each other very quickly which didn’t seem very believable given the supposed mixture of people on the island. 


One area where Btooom excels is the action scenes. Because the game uses different types of bombs the battles become a game of tactics and experience. Ryouta is one of the best Btooom players in the world and uses his skill to outwit opponents. Ryouta also appear to be fairly indestructible despite some close calls. 


The animation is by Madhouse so as you would expect it’s excellent. The battle scenes are fluid and the character designs are detailed and well drawn. 


Sound on Btooom is ok but the opening song is average at best but it doesn’t detract from the series or the atmosphere.


Btooom is an enjoyable action anime with weak characters and a fairly unoriginal plot. Perhaps the biggest issue with the series is that when it ends it feels it’s only half way through the story. A second season does not look likely which leaves you feeling short changed as your only getting half a story. It’s a shame we don’t get more Btooom as it’s a solid action anime and is defiantly worth a watch.

-Overall
BTOOOM! is a dark thriller where people have been sent to an island. The only way off the island is to use the bombs they are provided and a radar to kill 7 other people. Each person was randomly assigned a bomb type, so people don't know what to expect when fighting one another. The story of BTOOOM! is solid, and interesting. The art looks good, and can easily compare to modern day anime (BTOOOM! being from 2012. 2 years can make a big difference in visual quality.) The sound is average. The main characters are awfully bland, but the rest of the cast isinteresting enough. I thoroughly enjoyed this anime, and it got my heart beating fast. The action is enticing, the romance is decent enough, and I can't wait for a season 2. 

Story: 9

Art: 8.4

Sound: 7

Character: 7

Enjoyment: 9.15

Overall: 8.11. It's very good. 

More details down below.


-Story

The Story of BTOOOM! Is well crafted. The premise solid, interesting, and well explained. The plot is very good and not too predictable, which is refreshing for the Action genre. I can't say much without spoiling things, but I enjoyed the story very much.


-Art

The art is alright, pretty standard. It does look good for a 2012 anime, but it's nothing amazing. The artstyle for the eyes is different than usual, and may annoy some people. I didn't really care, but the eyes might be an issue for some.


-Sound

The voices are pretty good, and the soundtracks fit well, although that's pretty standard.


-Character

The main character, although he does have an interesting backstory, behaves and acts like a stereotypical male lead: brave, selfless, sympathetic, strong. And the main female lead acts like a stereotypical female lead. She has an interesting backstory, but acts essentially like the "Damsel in Distress" which is far too common and uninteresting. However, the supporting characters don't act nearly so archetypal, and I guess the 2 mains are more interesting than other main characters in the action genre *cough* Kirigaya Kazuto *cough*

Another problem I had with the main character, Sakamoto, is that he seems to have fluctuating intelligence. At times he's clever, crafty, and a master of deceit. At other times, he's dim-witted, unreasonably reckless, and all too trusting. For example, in the first episode, he can't seem to figure out that the bombs he has are timed bombs, despite seeing earlier a timer on the bomb counting down, and the bomb exploding when it reached zero. Other times he's a genius, out-manuevering and predicting his opponents like a boss.


-Enjoyment

This anime was one of the most thrilling shows I've seen in a while. The action is well-choreographed and the idea of using only bombs as weapons is interesting. My heart was beating hard and fast while I was watching this, and I can't wait for a season 2!

------------------------
| Btoom! : Review |
------------------------
Btoom! is an 12 action anime based on a manga by Junya Inoue and animated by one of my favorite Studios Madhouse. To be honest I really didn't expect much from this when I started watching this and I got what I expected. Would I recommend this to anyone ? Unlikely. Let's find out why 
-----------
Story - 3
-----------
Story of Btoom.., is nothing to write home about. The basic premise of the show is a bunch of people are put in a island , given bombs and instructed to kill each other to get off the island. And this itself is flawedbecause..., There's nothing really keeping them there, Just craft a boat and get the fuck out of there maybe ?

And as the series goes on , story doesn't really go anywhere and doesn't really have much of an ending. The supposed "twists" in the series are plain cheating , they clearly show us that happened and then later they show something completely different happened there ? How's that a twist ? That's plain cheating.

We can clearly see that this series tries to tackle a lot of mature subjects as it takes on matters such as rape and trauma but it has no idea what to do with those and saying it falls flat trying to tackle those would be an understatement , it absolutely humiliates itself. 


-----------------

Characters- 3

-----------------


Nope , nothing to see here.

The series doesn't manage to create interesting or "believe" characters. I highlight believable mainly because none of the characters feel human , even though that's what they are pushing for. Every character is extremely one dimensional having one trait that defines them and that's it.

The main character of series is neither interesting , likable or compelling. Only positive thing I can say about the main character is that he does receive some positive development towards end of the series. 

How story handles the characters brings down the plausibility even more , as every character is extremely dumb that even the most common thing to do is considered strategy. And have I mentioned how none of them ever gets injured (except one character) ? all the bombs , being blown away , jumping around and even falling from fetal heights.


------------------------------

Sound and Animation- 6

------------------------------


I'm going to keep this section extremely short because there really isn't much to talk about here. Both sound and animations are competent , nothing special and nothing bad. Character designs are admittedly pretty good. Animation is done by Studio Madhouse so no worries there as they always deliver. Soundtrack is nothing notable and the Opening Theme is actually pretty good.


-----------------------------------------------

Enjoyment and Overall Experience - 4

-----------------------------------------------


This is an extremely passable but watchable anime. Would I recommend it ? No , there are much better alternatives (Not SAO) , If you want a spectacle of explosions go watch a Micheal Bay movie or Black Lagoon (Black Lagoon preferably).

So do yourself a favor and just pass on this one.

This is an awesome version of the island death match "Battle Royale" concept, except everyone has special bombs and radar. The only problem is that the entire show is about rape. The female protagonist is a busty blonde whose backstory is she got a bunch of her friends raped. This is actually all they do to tell us about who she is. Now she's on this island with bombs and radar and needs to kill people to survive. So of course the logical next step is that every man she encounters is doing everything he possibly can to force himself sexually upon her. You know,because she only has tons of bombs and radar to defend herself, so it only makes sense. \n\n
Sound is standard. Art and animation is slightly above average. Would have been a great show if they only ever stuck to the male protagonist. The writer is so mind numbingly obsessed with trying to rape this girl you'd almost think he was trying to tell you something. Even the high moral male protagonist has his moment.

the show needed more episode for it really to have been done perfectly but for we got i absolutely loved it.  all the characters in the show are villains in some form as that is what got them put into the game in the first place. i really like this and it really comes to play later in story (the source material).  also despite the time constraints this show has they had really well-paced character development, it shows how our main characters get affected mentally by the game as some go crazy or selfish. if you decide to watch i really suggest notstopping at the point the show ends and continuing the story in the source material as it covers up things that other reviews point out as flaws as the flaws in the characters and story are essential but don't come into play yet.

is an anime that struck me a lot as online sword art at the beginning the main character is the strongest player in the online game btooom is a nett (singular nerd). The development of the plot itself works, the characters are realistic, sensible ideas, reasonable plans. Even the situations are quite different from each other, despite having bombs in common. The only thing that does not convince me is why these guys are brought to the island. But the real problem with this series is that everything that happens is already seen. We are facing the umpteenth clone of "Battle Royale", if not theleast original of its copies, the most similar to it. Another thing that upsets the nose and not a little is that the story is incomplete: in fact in the last five years there has been no follow-up and it can be deduced that the project has been canceled.\n
Reading the plot I was intrigued and given to the mad joy because when there is an anime that stands out the survival I do expect it, putting myself comfortable on the sofa and watching it until the end.\n
 Summing up the plot, Ryouta Sakamoto is a twenty-two year old unemployed who spends his days playing a video game, BTOOM, where he is one of the best, does not have a good relationship with his mother and almost always ends up being indecent. My review is based on the first episode. I couldn't get past it.
So the anime starts normally, get to see the protagonist, his hobby, ...
Then he gets sucked in the game he rocks but then, everything fell apart.
So the guy, finds cubes in a satchel, presses on a button on one of the cubes he took, sees a freaking countdown, understood something was off, throws it to realise it was a timed bomb. To then later on, having NO FREAKING CLUE he had to press to active these timed bombs, and no having NO FREAKING CLUE, even tho there's a freaking timer on em, thatthey're timed bombs? If that's just episode one, I can even imagine how stupid the rest of this anime can be... If you're the same kind of person as me, where that level of stupidity irritates you, don't even bother with this one.

Heads up! This anime just stops mid story. If you cant stand cliffhangers or uncompleted anime watch it at your own risk. OK on with reviewy stuff.
Video 1/1: The art is a mixed bag I think, the quality seems a tad lower than it should be, but on the other hand animation is really smooth.
Audio 1/1: I'm not great at judging sound stuff, but it seemed to rather well be done when it mattered, and wasn't a problem the rest of the time.
Story 2/3: This is where we get to the crux of it, BTOOOM!'s story is great, and I mean it, the premise isintriguing, the sequence of events is compelling and the characters all act in ways that make sense. No one is comically evil, no one is fairy tale good. Every character makes their decisions based on their past, their perceptions of the present and an expectation of future outcomes. Like real people do! No one does something just because it is important for the plot to move forward. Furthermore the characters speak in sentences of length befitting the situation, unlike how in some anime people are cripplingly verbose in the middle of a fight and the fight just suddenly lulls to allow this character to speak a whole paragraph.\n\n
On the bad though, due to the shortness of the anime's run, the characters seem, to me at least, a little undeveloped. I think that had they not rushed out to make this and instead waited for the manga to finish then they could have had a longer schedule, thus extending the character building scenes and also (obviously) not had the story suddenly stop in the middle.

Before I review this I want to state that this is my opinion and you may agree or disagree at your own will.
Review:
Btooom! is a pretty good anime but it has it's faults. Starting with Btooom!'s intro. It fits the anime perfectly and it hypes you up from the start and every time you hear this opening you'll get excited for each episode. Character wise the show has many interesting characters even though when some feel generic anime cliche characters. The MC isn't one of those OP characters that everyone who is afraid of but he does have a respectful part in the plot ofthe show but at the same time he isn't some pussy who just gets whooped and relies on his girl to do everything. I mean I am all fine for a strong female or females to lead the show I've watched plenty of anime that have those but when the male characters can't do anything for themselves and are like a lost puppy it pisses me off. Btooom!'s MC in our case is the perfect balance where you kinda get worried if he's going to eat it or not. The love interest in this show is done pretty well. She has a huge character progression from the beginning to the end and it's done very well. Plot wise it's okay. It's one of those anime that a game becomes a reality but has a nice twist too it because the main weapon of choice is grenades with different effects to them. The only problem is that they don't really go into the plot of the show. By the end of the last episode I was kinda disappointed not because how it ended but because the realization hit me that I didn't know the reason they were doing any of this. All in all Btoom! was a good anime but wasn't as good as it could've been.

Year 2012 was a good year for anime, it gave us shows like Another, K and Chuunibyou demo koi ga Shitai and then there's Btooom! 
Our main lead is a 22 year old Neet who finds himself on a deserted tropical island were he and several other people mush fight each other using only bombs! Just like the online game Btoom he used to play. 
It's a situation were either kill or be killed and the fittest shall survive. It's not every day when you come across a survival anime with this execution. 
I have to say I was really drawn to Btoom!'s story thatI watched the whole thing in 6 continuous hours. The idea of choosing people you would wish to disappear and for them to actually disappear only to be taken into this "game" was really good! 

We get to learn about the characters backgrounds, some you'll sympathize with and some you'd wish they'd just go and die, your emotions will be completely moved by each development. 


The fight scenes are great, I was initially worried about the idea of ONLY using bombs, but that thought was soon forgotten seeing how cool is it to use each kind of BIMs for different purposes. 

Those fights would be so intense that sometimes you'll be at the edge of your seat watching everything closely waiting to see what shall happen next.

If there's one thing for sure, gaming experience can save your ass in here lol. 


It is rare when you see a show that only gets better, each episode is better than the last, it brought the game out to be played in real life to be played by real people who got nothing but their survival instinct, luck and a whole lot of Bombs to make it out of the island safe. 

The art wasn't consistent at times but that's about the only little issue in the show, the sound was amazing the two openings are awesome and the voice acting as well.


Well, as you can already tell, I really liked this anime, made me want to go straight and review it, cause it's not everyday you come across an anime that is trying to be something and something different than the other shows you've seen. It just pains my heart to know that this was the worst selling anime for 2012 :/ 

It was not perfect, no, but it gave me a thrilling experience and I was definitely entertained and in the end that's what it matters...

Btooom is a survival/ suspense style anime focused on male lead Ryota struggling to survive on an island where he and others are forced into a survival game based off an online video game that he is one of the top global players on. The series mixes focus between exploring how Ryota and several others wind up on the island and the players finding themselves trying to survive against one another using their wits and the various bombs they have in their possession to kill off one another. In its focus on the main leads and some of the other players, Btooom does very wellin focusing on the issues faced by them as the series explores the circumstances and personal flaws that led each character on the island and how the survival game affects their psyche, with Ryota, Himiko and Taira's stories getting the best development among the bunch. The dynamics of the survival game are also engaging to see as each of the bombs fulfill specific functions that are reliable depending on the player's present scenario and each player exploits the battle environment, manipulation, their personal experiences and some luck with the real life/ online game to take advantage of any opportunity they can get to cripple or kill off their foe(s), making for genuinely suspenseful moments when Himiko and Ryota deal with rival players. The series also delves into the moral ramifications of the game as Ryota and some other characters deal with the circumstances of their life-and-death game in differing ways with mentalities varying between every person for themselves, breaking down from the lack of contact with trustworthy folk and trying to hold onto whatever morality possible.


Praises aside though, Btooom does have its fair share of issues that keep me from wanting to rate it higher. Some characters on the island don't get much in the way of depth and background, existing either to serve as obstacles in Ryota and Himiko's struggle for survival or to relish in some form of depravity, with one over-the-top case being a 14-year old murderer/ necrophiliac. Also, the means in which the survival game gets pulled off does stretch believability quite a bit with the means the video game company behind the Btooom video game pull off and get away with their acts. The series is also left open-ended as Ryota and Himiko are still on the island and several elements to the series that are hinted to are left unresolved.


Visually, Btooom's presentation is a bit on the plain side. Scenery shots of the island and city landscapes coming from flashbacks are nicely drawn with vivid, restrained color and plenty of detail. There is a good amount of diversity in the designs employed for characters to give the series a realistic feel, though they lack the heavy level of detail given to scenery. The animation to the series is okay, though mostly highlighted with any explosions and collateral damage that result from bombs going off and lacking the fluid and smooth frame rate that TV anime like Psycho-Pass and Fate/Zero 2 had from 2012.


While having its fair share of issues, Btooom is still a solid entry in the suspense anime genre in its focus on Ryota and Himiko's survival in a real-life version of the online game that they were a regular part of with its original premise and focus on the mental toll that the game pushes on some of the major characters.

Love big explosions and bombs? Yes! Love hot schoolgirls? Hell yeah! Love blood and gore in anime?  Not really, but its alright. Now combine them altogether. The end result you get BTOOOM!! Of course, what people is looking for, is a good story, 'fraid to say that BTOOOM!!'s story doesn't sound that bad at first sight; 22-year old Ryouta Sakamoto finds himself playing his favourite online game...in real life fashion. Anyway, I'll try my best not to include spoilers in this review. This anime is all about survival and action.
Honestly, the whole concept sounds a little Battle Royale-ish, but after watching the entire seriesof 12 episodes, It wasn't that great. It's not that bad either. Let's just say that, the story is somewhat rushed in a way, and also I still can't quite get  Let's start by first talking about the characters. The characters consists of commoners of varying age forced to play a online game recreated in a real life situation. However, 90% of the characters were pretty ugly, to be honest. Not saying that all anime should consists of hot and perfect-looking characters, but still most of the characters in this anime had annoying attitudes and few were made to look so ugly just to be killed.


The biggest problem? Most of the explosions aren't "realistic". You see, in one episode, a man died a horrible death due to a bomb that detonated right below him. And then, in another episode, another person survived the exact same bomb type that detonated close behind him. How the hell did he survive a huge explosion that close? Not only that, he survived with having few minor burns. Totally unrealistic. Probably just a way to keep the "important" characters alive throughout the show.


Another minor problem I have; its about the protagonist. Well, he's pretty alright though, but then, how he can "predict" and tell whats going to happen next is so...amazing. Almost like he has some kind of psychic power. It's like most of his plan always goes according to it. It's like he can tell what the enemy is going to do next; its like he can read their minds or something. 


The types of bombs used in the series have unique designs, especially the implosion-type bomb. But few of the bombs were so underused, for example, as far as I can recall, there was only one character that had a certain type of bomb that no other players had. I won't spoil what type of bomb and which character had that type. If they made some really unique bomb designs, why not make use of them? Also, the main concept of the anime is bombs, so there's no other weapons besides them. So, if you like Guns or Swords, you'll probably won't find BTOOOM! that interesting.


The art and graphics? are actually quite stunning. The 3D-effects for some of the bombs looks superb at the very least, and the environment looks nicely polished. Nothing much to complain about the art and graphics. Character art and designs also look great. For example, Himiko's clothing design. The army-camo colored skirt and tie does look awesome. But it still makes me wonder how'd she got hold onto it and why she wearing it before she got sent to the island.


The Sound? The Opening theme, No Pain, no game is over-the-top and I always loved listening to it. The ending theme in my opinion, isn't really my type though. Since music genre is from one's personal view, so I only listened to the ending theme once and never again. Hint - There's a 2nd opening theme saved for the last and in my opinion, it's way better than the first opening.


Final verdict? Overall, BTOOOM!! does have its good parts in most of the series, but it's still a little half-baked.In the end, I was rather disappointed after watching the whole anime since BTOOOM!! have A LOT of potential of becoming a great anime, the reason why 'cause I really like Battle Royale-ish shows/anime/movie. But in my opinion, if you do like action-genre or survival of the fittest-type anime, why not just give BTOOOM!! a try? Who knows, you might actually like it more than I do.

This anime is about Ryouta Sakamoto the #10 ranked player in the online game Bto0om!. He wakes up in the middle of the wood, only to find out that he now is a part of a real Btooom! game. The game Btoom is like a FPS game but Btooom! only uses bombs, if you have seen the movie Hunger Games or Battle Royale then this is kinda like it.
Story: As it's not the most original story it's still one i enjoy, they manage to keep it intressting so that everything doesn't feel like it's the same episode all over again.
Art: The art style is muchthe same as other action animes, in Btooom! they manage to draw explosions very good.


Sound: The sound track was really good, it always keept me focused in the story and made me excited. The intro "No pain, No gain" is one of my favorite intro songs.


Character: They have a broad variet of characters, every thing from children to mercenaries.


Enjoyment: I love exciting animes with action, love and betrayal, and this anime has it all.

Btooom! has a really nice subject and... I was hoping it would develop more from there, because bringing a game to reality, forcing the people to kill each other and to survive it's something BIG! But Btooom! is not. Still, it's enjoyable and a good waste of time. And since I'm in a positive mood today I will hope that the next season (if it's going to be one, though it kinda implies so) will be 10 times greater than this one.
Story: Our protagonist, Ryouta, finds himself trapped on an island forced to do anything in his power to survive. Soon after he realizes thathe is constrained to play Btooom!, his favourite virtual game, but in the real world.


Art: The graphic part of Btooom! has a lot to offer. The animation is smooth and pretty awesome, the background is magnificent. The characters design isn't really my type, but it's unique.


Sound: The greatest part of this show!


Characters: Well... they annoyed me a lot. I find them a little bit exaggerated and predictable. From a psychological anime I was expecting more.


And despite not doing an amazing thing with the story and having boring characters, I truly enjoyed it! I can't really explain why but as long as the show kept me there, waiting for the next episode it must have done something good, right?

Btooom! is a show where a video game becomes reality. Many players of the infamous japanese game known as Btooom! are dropped into an island to play the game for real and fight for survival. The show art and sound were very good. Since the game is played using primarily bombs and tactics, lots of explosion audio and art was used. It was all done very well. My problem with it was the characters werent really that lovable. I didnt feel compassionate about them as much as other anime ive seen. Overall the show is very good and an interesting apporach to a first personshooter game perspective. Its story line isnt that good because it has been used in many other anime series.

Dominate on Counter Strike or Battlefield? Perfect, now we'll force you to join it for real! Btooom is a twist on the Battle Royale premise where ordinary people, who have been selected as "unwanted" by others, are dumped on an abandoned island and forced to play the video game Btooom in real life. What is Btooom? It's a game where people utilize bombs and "sonar" pulses to find and destroy each other. Luckily, our protagonist is one of the top Btooom players in the world. Will his "virtual" experience help him survive the real version of the game?
First and foremost, viewers beware, this series' endingis as compete as that in HSOTD. Imagine watching the original Battle Royale halfway and just stopping; that's pretty much the current conclusion for this series. Second, if you're tired of how mainstream video gaming has become in anime, avoid this as well. Third, if you don't like the protagonist "magically" surviving what can only be described as certain death repeatedly I'd pass on this as well. For all of you who this has not yet dissuaded, continue reading.


Animation:

The animation quality of the series is mixed. Overall lighting is above average and there is a good range of beautiful island scenery and darker, more tense moments. The drawing clarity and detail could be better at times but it doesn't necessarily stand out as a negative. One thing I did notice was how miraculous it was that the main characters still had clean clothes after days of fighting and blowing each other up. As for character styling, the main heroine has somewhat wide eyes that remind me of Key's old works. It was also convenient how her Btooom game avatar was close to how she looks in real life whereas Ryouta looks like a generic dude.


There's substantial sexual abuse, violence, and some gore in this show that make it inappropriate for those under 13. The camera does turn away at critical moments, and at one point utilizes an ugly black filter that covers half the screen- talk about laziness... Expect plenty of explosions, blood, and effects.


Sound:

Btooom utilizes a heavy rock jpop OP, which then strangely changes to a new OP by the same band in the last episode as if to signal a new arc. The ED is a cool down, mellow piece that has a distinctively unpleasant tune for me. The BGM fares better with an interesting mix of brass and some vocal work similar to the fight songs in Persona 4.


The cast is fairly average overall. I think it would have been a bit more realistic if every other person on the island didn't sound like they were already insane.


Story:

While it's true that there are now pro racing car drivers that were picked for their virtual driving skills, I don't think that carries over so well here. The idea is that the company that created Btooom is abducting "unwanted" people to do research for an unspecified purpose, perhaps some form of the battles between players in Zetman. Looking past the not-so-realistic premise, the show plays as a relatively entertaining thriller that's told from the perspective of multiple participants- each one trying to guess the intentions of everyone else.

The story often uses flashbacks and monologues to give background or explanation, some of which is overused.


Plot-wise, expect a fair variety of plot twists and cliffhangers. After awhile, I stopped being thrilled by the survival aspect of the show and migrated more into a guessing pattern as to how the protagonist would miraculously escape the next impossible situation. There is a huge plot shield on important characters, and it really takes away from the overall experience. As mentioned before, the story does build in tension until the last episode where it just sort of stops. No one rides a roller coaster to the top of the hill and decides "OK that was a great ride let's move on". I'm assuming that there will be a follow up but, regardless, this was poor execution.


Character:

Our protagonist, while a god in the virtual world, is just an average NEET in the real world; he's afraid of dying but doesn't want to kill anyone. Sound like anyone? Indeed, also like Kira Yamato, Ryouta is able to summon what amounts to SEED mode when he's pushed to a corner, somehow magically gaining foresight and instant athletic reflexes. There is supposed to be development with the characters as they grow to trust and interact with each other. However, Ryouta is just your typical anti-social dude who (strangely enough) trusts everyone without second thoughts. The story does play a bit with romance as Ryouta and Himiko had previously met in the online world but it was downplayed and ultimately had very little impact on where the story goes.


As for supporting cast, most of them are all antagonists and vilified to the point that it makes Mirai Nikki look good, which is quite saddening. Due to the huge plot shield and minimal character exposure/weird character behavior I found it quite difficult to connect with the characters.


Value:

While a fairly entertaining thriller early on, Btooom implodes when it comes to plot progression and character interactions. It fails to sell its premise and serves only to mock gamers. I may modify this if ever a second series appears but in the meantime, it wasn't worth the six hours.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Story: 8 - The plot line is very well defined from beginning to end.
Art: 7 - Not the best art for anime, especially in this era but still passable.
Sound: 7 - Well defined sound effects but not the impact I was hoping for.
Character: 10 - Every character has his or  her own story which shapes them into who they are.
Enjoyment: 8 - Only if you like blood and "kill or be killed" types of anime
Overall 8.0 - Brilliantly well played out anime and I am of course hoping for more! 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Let the 76th annual Hunger Games begin! 
But wait, we are not in Panem, we are in Japan. Soo, the survivor games are not called "The Hunger Games" but "Btooom!". Considering this, today's anime review would be "Btooom!"
Plot and Storyline
As mentioned in the intro, this anime really reminded me of The Hunger Games. And now you'll hear why. The story is set in a world where currently a very popular game called Batoom! is infecting the life of millions all around the world. One of the world's best players is Ryouta Sakamoto. He is a need without a job that only lives for that game.One day he suddenly wakes up hanging with a parachute from a tree in a jungle. He didn't know where he was or what happened to him, but soon he will find out. While walking on that lonely island a man attacked him with bombs, trying to kill him of curse. That's when he realized. He was trapped on that island by the makers of Btooom! along with others being forced to play the game for real. The rules are the same as in the game. Use only bombs, and each player gets another type of bombs.You have to kill at least seven people and take their crystals if you want to escape the island alive. The thing I found most interesting about this anime is the way the players were selected. I don't want to spoil you that, but I promise that kinda represents the sickness of our society. \n
This anime, how I think, is first of all a psychological one. The anime deals with the mind of people like non other. The whole time it was about the thought of killing others just to save your own life. What is more important, a life of someone or your own? A question that forced a lot of people to loose their mind on the island. But we also have the ones that didn't need a second thought and mercilessly killed to survive. The ones responsible for this kinda made of it a TV show but not everybody can watch it. What ever, the real-life-game looks like a psychology experiment done by a crazy scientist where he wants to understand the nature of soul it self. \n
A cute, little romance is also also a part of this whole story. The fact that surprised me is that they kinda confessed to each other in the end, whats mostly unlikely in an anime to happen.  The\n
The show also doesn't lack in action and funny moments. It is an exciting story with no plot holes that only makes you want more and more. The only question that is left open in the end is "Where is season two?". Honestly now, this is not the greatest anime I've watched but it definitely deserves another season. Besides, the story is unfinished soo...\n\n
Characters\n
It is a psychological anime so it implies that you get the chance to "meet" each character and learn about their personality. You have a colorful bunch of characteristics from needs, to 14-year-old psychos and rapers. Here for you I have the two mains:\n
RYOUTA  SAKAMOTO is a typical NEED character without a job in his twenties. As he later realizes he always cared just about his self, making it look like he does things for others. But despite that he knew that it is not human to kill others just to survive. Ryouta experiences a huge character development and becomes a responsible young man that knows what he has to change in his life. \n
As one of the few female characters HIMIKO's life on the island becomes real hell. In the beginning of the story Himiko becomes a victim of raping and turns into a man hating girl right after that. In a situation of death or being raped she rather chooses death. That's a thing I admire about her. She later on gains trust in men after meeting Ryouta, but her fear never disappears. A strong female character that maked the story even more interesting. \n\n
Animation \n
The animation of this anime is really good. I liked it. The action scenes and bombs are well done just like all the characters in this anime. The landscapes are also beautiful and mostly bright but also dark where it should be. There is nothing much to talk about animation. I'd give it a 8/10. Nice work! \n\n
Conclusion                                           \n
 This anime is definitely a show I would recommend you to watch. It is catchy, interesting, and enjoyable to watch. It is rich in action and all that psychological stuff makes you very curious.  What I have to say about this anime is that it honestly looks like a mix of Hunger Games and Sword Art Online, but it is not bad. \n
It is rich in background stories but doesn't leave plot holes at all. I loved it, I think you will too, so give it a try.\n
Your AnimeGirl

Btooom! begins with the fairly predictable premise of a death game similar to the ranks of Hunger Games, but with a psychological twist. It attempts to reveal the primitive nature of people when all is at stake, putting their morality and conscience to the test, all the while using the BIMs to add action to the plot. There are many who point out inconsistencies between the characters where flashbacks are concerned, which has a simple explanation: People are different over time and when around others. It examines what are called reverse prejudices, where generally oppressed figures are seen discriminating against the majority. Sakomoto and Himikostruggle with horrible experiences and finally find solace with each other, if that's worth anything. The short span of episodes do make it difficult to grasp the purpose of this game and the motives of the characters, making the ending rather unfulfilling and rushed. Still, all in all, I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys genres of psychology and action. Go ahead, have a blast.

The "fight-to-the-death" genre isn't a new one, with shows like Mirai Nikki and Deadman Wonderland having saturated the anime market in past years. While there's nothing inherently wrong with this genre, it can quickly go downhill if not handled carefully, and in BTOOOM!'s case, I'd say that's what happened.         
I wanted to like this; I really did. But it fell flat in my opinion, and here's why.
PLOT
Ryota Sakamoto is a NEET, and an avid video game player at that. So much so, that he manages to seize his spot as one of the world's top players for the online action battle game, BTOOOM. One day, Ryota’s reclusive lifestyle is suddenlyturned upside down when he inexplicably wakes up on an island with others who are trying to kill him. Vowing not to play this real-life version of the game he’s spent so long perfecting, he is determined to stick together with the other players and survive. 


The very reason for why Ryota and the other characters were sent to the island in the first place is briefly mentioned a few times, and we do get glimpses of who exactly is pulling the strings for this death match, but it's still not explained very well. They're portrayed as these evil people who joyously clap their hands together like a circus seal while watching the contestants in their twisted game kill each other off. There's not much explanation for why any of this is happening (I only remember them mentioning their motive only once or twice). In fact, the whole plot is so rushed that making sense of any of it is difficult. We don't even get any sort of resolution; the end is incredibly abrupt, and considering the buildup until that point, you'd think there'd be some sort of payoff, but unfortunately we're not that lucky. A cliffhanger like that would have worked if they were planning on making a sequel, but since the second season never came to fruition, it's just frustrating and confusing.


CHARACTERS

You don’t really see a lot of the other characters until halfway through the anime, despite the flashback scene to the airplane clearly showing around 20 or so of them. When they do show up, they’re killed off before you have a chance to comprehend what’s going on, they just simply disappear, or not much is explained about them so you’re left with these cardboard cutouts of people. In fact, I found myself skipping a few minutes at a time here and there because things were just… really not going anywhere, honestly. Considering this is a death match, I was expecting a bit more tension and action.


Ryota has a bit of a plot armor problem, enough to make Yuno Gasai proud . Almost every explosion that happens, he manages to dodge without so much as a scratch. Meanwhile, Taira and Himiko are getting the shit kicked out of them by everything that comes their way, but Ryota’s perfectly fine. Literally, I barely blinked an eye when an explosion occurred because I pretty much knew Ryota would survive it anyway. The only time he ever gets severely injured is because it's convenient to the plot, and even then he wasn't as hurt as he should have been.


Himiko, too, has issues of her own. She constantly switches between the damsel in distress and the badass female lead depending on what's going on. It's hard to really tack down a main personality trait for her since her character has such drastic mood swings. And honestly, her tragic backstory™ was unnecessary. The studio seemed more preoccupied with finding ways to add shock value to BTOOOM! rather than handling such serious issues in an intelligent manner. This is evidenced by how afraid she is at first of everyone, including Ryota and Taira, and then magically manages to overcome her trauma within a short period of time because... drum roll... she starts to fall in love with Ryota. C'mon, really? While I've never been a victim of sexual assault, I do know that it oftentimes takes years, to overcome something so terrible. But I guess it doesn't matter with this anime, since it's proved that as long as long as it's convenient to the plot, anything goes.


ART + SOUND


The art is better than what I expected, and while it is pretty decent, it’s a bit lackluster. The studio's budget seems to have gone into the backgrounds more so than the actual characters, but oh well. As for sound, I was told the OP was pretty good, and I have to agree! I didn't like it too much at first, so I skipped it; then when I took the time to listen to the whole thing I couldn't stop. It's catchy as hell, that's for sure. 


Overall rating: 4/10
